17656.text: §¶These are the visions that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem. He saw these visions during the years when Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were kings of Judah.

17657.text: §¶Listen, O heavens! Pay attention, earth!/_This is what the Lord says:/“The children I raised and cared for/_have rebelled against me.

17658.text: /Even an ox knows its owner,/_and a donkey recognizes its master’s care—/but Israel doesn’t know its master./_My people don’t recognize my care for them.”

17659.text: /Oh, what a sinful nation they are—/_loaded down with a burden of guilt./They are evil people,/_corrupt children who have rejected the Lord./They have despised the Holy One of Israel/_and turned their backs on him.

17660.text: ¶Why do you continue to invite punishment?/_Must you rebel forever?/Your head is injured,/_and your heart is sick.

17661.text: /You are battered from head to foot—/_covered with bruises, welts, and infected wounds—/_without any soothing ointments or bandages.

17662.text: /Your country lies in ruins,/_and your towns are burned./Foreigners plunder your fields before your eyes/_and destroy everything they see.

17663.text: /Beautiful Jerusalem stands abandoned/_like a watchman’s shelter in a vineyard,/like a lean‐to in a cucumber field after the harvest,/_like a helpless city under siege.

17664.text: /If the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_had not spared a few of us,/we would have been wiped out like Sodom,/_destroyed like Gomorrah.

17665.text: ¶Listen to the Lord, you leaders of “Sodom.”/_Listen to the law of our God, people of “Gomorrah.”

17666.text: /“What makes you think I want all your sacrifices?”/_says the Lord./“I am sick of your burnt offerings of rams/_and the fat of fattened cattle./I get no pleasure from the blood/_of bulls and lambs and goats.

17667.text: /When you come to worship me,/_who asked you to parade through my courts with all your ceremony?

17668.text: /Stop bringing me your meaningless gifts;/_the incense of your offerings disgusts me!/As for your celebrations of the new moon and the Sabbath/_and your special days for fasting—/they are all sinful and false./_I want no more of your pious meetings.

17669.text: /I hate your new moon celebrations and your annual festivals./_They are a burden to me. I cannot stand them!

17670.text: /When you lift up your hands in prayer, I will not look./_Though you offer many prayers, I will not listen,/_for your hands are covered with the blood of innocent victims.

17671.text: /Wash yourselves and be clean!/_Get your sins out of my sight./_Give up your evil ways.

17672.text: /Learn to do good./_Seek justice./Help the oppressed./_Defend the cause of orphans./_Fight for the rights of widows.

17673.text: ¶“Come now, let’s settle this,”/_says the Lord./“Though your sins are like scarlet,/_I will make them as white as snow./Though they are red like crimson,/_I will make them as white as wool.

17674.text: /If you will only obey me,/_you will have plenty to eat.

17675.text: /But if you turn away and refuse to listen,/_you will be devoured by the sword of your enemies./_I, the Lord, have spoken!”

17676.text: §¶See how Jerusalem, once so faithful,/_has become a prostitute./Once the home of justice and righteousness,/_she is now filled with murderers.

17677.text: /Once like pure silver,/_you have become like worthless slag./Once so pure,/_you are now like watered‐down wine.

17678.text: /Your leaders are rebels,/_the companions of thieves./All of them love bribes/_and demand payoffs,/but they refuse to defend the cause of orphans/_or fight for the rights of widows.

17679.text: ¶Therefore, the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_the Mighty One of Israel, says,/“I will take revenge on my enemies/_and pay back my foes!

17680.text: /I will raise my fist against you./_I will melt you down and skim off your slag./_I will remove all your impurities.

17681.text: /Then I will give you good judges again/_and wise counselors like you used to have./Then Jerusalem will again be called the Home of Justice/_and the Faithful City.”

17682.text: ¶Zion will be restored by justice;/_those who repent will be revived by righteousness.

17683.text: /But rebels and sinners will be completely destroyed,/_and those who desert the Lord will be consumed.

17684.text: ¶You will be ashamed of your idol worship/_in groves of sacred oaks./You will blush because you worshiped/_in gardens dedicated to idols.

17685.text: /You will be like a great tree with withered leaves,/_like a garden without water.

17686.text: /The strongest among you will disappear like straw;/_their evil deeds will be the spark that sets it on fire./They and their evil works will burn up together,/_and no one will be able to put out the fire.

17687.text: §¶This is a vision that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

17688.text: ¶In the last days, the mountain of the Lord’s house/_will be the highest of all—/_the most important place on earth./It will be raised above the other hills,/_and people from all over the world will stream there to worship.

17689.text: /People from many nations will come and say,/“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,/_to the house of Jacob’s God./There he will teach us his ways,/_and we will walk in his paths.”/For the Lord’s teaching will go out from Zion;/_his word will go out from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /The Lord will mediate between nations/_and will settle international disputes./They will hammer their swords into plowshares/_and their spears into pruning hooks./Nation will no longer fight against nation,/_nor train for war anymore.

17691.text: §¶Come, descendants of Jacob,/_let us walk in the light of the Lord!

17692.text: /For the Lord has rejected his people,/_the descendants of Jacob,/because they have filled their land with practices from the East/_and with sorcerers, as the Philistines do./_They have made alliances with pagans.

17693.text: /Israel is full of silver and gold;/_there is no end to its treasures./Their land is full of warhorses;/_there is no end to its chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is full of idols;/_the people worship things they have made/_with their own hands.

17695.text: /So now they will be humbled,/_and all will be brought low—/_do not forgive them.

17696.text: /Crawl into caves in the rocks./_Hide in the dust/from the terror of the Lord/_and the glory of his majesty.

17697.text: /Human pride will be brought down,/_and human arrogance will be humbled./Only the Lord will be exalted/_on that day of judgment.

17698.text: ¶For the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_has a day of reckoning./He will punish the proud and mighty/_and bring down everything that is exalted.

17699.text: /He will cut down the tall cedars of Lebanon/_and all the mighty oaks of Bashan.

17700.text: /He will level all the high mountains/_and all the lofty hills.

17701.text: /He will break down every high tower/_and every fortified wall.

17702.text: /He will destroy all the great trading ships/_and every magnificent vessel.

17703.text: /Human pride will be humbled,/_and human arrogance will be brought down./Only the Lord will be exalted/_on that day of judgment.

17705.text: /When the Lord rises to shake the earth,/_his enemies will crawl into holes in the ground./They will hide in caves in the rocks/_from the terror of the Lord/_and the glory of his majesty.

17706.text: /On that day of judgment they will abandon the gold and silver idols/_they made for themselves to worship./They will leave their gods to the rodents and bats,

17707.text: /_while they crawl away into caverns/_and hide among the jagged rocks in the cliffs./They will try to escape the terror of the Lord/_and the glory of his majesty/_as he rises to shake the earth.

17708.text: /Don’t put your trust in mere humans./_They are as frail as breath./_What good are they?

17709.text: §¶The Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_will take away from Jerusalem and Judah/everything they depend on:/_every bit of bread/_and every drop of water,

17710.text: /all their heroes and soldiers,/_judges and prophets,/_fortune‐tellers and elders,

17711.text: /army officers and high officials,/_advisers, skilled sorcerers, and astrologers.

17712.text: ¶I will make boys their leaders,/_and toddlers their rulers.

17713.text: /People will oppress each other—/_man against man,/_neighbor against neighbor./Young people will insult their elders,/_and vulgar people will sneer at the honorable.

17714.text: ¶In those days a man will say to his brother,/“Since you have a coat, you be our leader!/_Take charge of this heap of ruins!”

17715.text: /But he will reply,/_“No! I can’t help./I don’t have any extra food or clothes./_Don’t put me in charge!”

17716.text: ¶For Jerusalem will stumble,/_and Judah will fall,/because they speak out against the Lord and refuse to obey him./_They provoke him to his face.

17717.text: /The very look on their faces gives them away./_They display their sin like the people of Sodom/_and don’t even try to hide it./They are doomed!/_They have brought destruction upon themselves.

17718.text: ¶Tell the godly that all will be well for them./_They will enjoy the rich reward they have earned!

17719.text: /But the wicked are doomed,/_for they will get exactly what they deserve.

17720.text: ¶Childish leaders oppress my people,/_and women rule over them./O my people, your leaders mislead you;/_they send you down the wrong road.

17721.text: ¶The Lord takes his place in court/_and presents his case against his people.

17722.text: /The Lord comes forward to pronounce judgment/_on the elders and rulers of his people:/“You have ruined Israel, my vineyard./_Your houses are filled with things stolen from the poor.

17723.text: /How dare you crush my people,/_grinding the faces of the poor into the dust?”/_demands the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

17724.text: §¶The Lord says, “Beautiful Zion is haughty:/craning her elegant neck,/_flirting with her eyes,/walking with dainty steps,/_tinkling her ankle bracelets.

17725.text: /So the Lord will send scabs on her head;/_the Lord will make beautiful Zion bald.”

17726.text: ¶On that day of judgment/_the Lord will strip away everything that makes her beautiful:/ornaments, headbands, crescent necklaces,

17731.text: /mirrors, fine linen garments,/_head ornaments, and shawls.

17732.text: ¶Instead of smelling of sweet perfume, she will stink./_She will wear a rope for a sash,/_and her elegant hair will fall out./She will wear rough burlap instead of rich robes./_Shame will replace her beauty.

17733.text: /The men of the city will be killed with the sword,/_and her warriors will die in battle.

17734.text: /The gates of Zion will weep and mourn./_The city will be like a ravaged woman,/_huddled on the ground.

17735.text: ¶In that day so few men will be left that seven women will fight for each man, saying, “Let us all marry you! We will provide our own food and clothing. Only let us take your name so we won’t be mocked as old maids.”

17736.text: §¶But in that day, the branch of the Lord/_will be beautiful and glorious;/the fruit of the land will be the pride and glory/_of all who survive in Israel.

17737.text: /All who remain in Zion/_will be a holy people—/those who survive the destruction of Jerusalem/_and are recorded among the living.

17738.text: /The Lord will wash the filth from beautiful Zion/_and cleanse Jerusalem of its bloodstains/_with the hot breath of fiery judgment.

17739.text: /Then the Lord will provide shade for Mount Zion/_and all who assemble there./He will provide a canopy of cloud during the day/_and smoke and flaming fire at night,/_covering the glorious land.

17740.text: /It will be a shelter from daytime heat/_and a hiding place from storms and rain.

17741.text: §¶Now I will sing for the one I love/_a song about his vineyard:/My beloved had a vineyard/_on a rich and fertile hill.

17742.text: /He plowed the land, cleared its stones,/_and planted it with the best vines./In the middle he built a watchtower/_and carved a winepress in the nearby rocks./Then he waited for a harvest of sweet grapes,/_but the grapes that grew were bitter.

17743.text: ¶Now, you people of Jerusalem and Judah,/_you judge between me and my vineyard.

17744.text: /What more could I have done for my vineyard/_that I have not already done?/When I expected sweet grapes,/_why did my vineyard give me bitter grapes?

17745.text: ¶Now let me tell you/_what I will do to my vineyard:/I will tear down its hedges/_and let it be destroyed./I will break down its walls/_and let the animals trample it.

17746.text: /I will make it a wild place/_where the vines are not pruned and the ground is not hoed,/_a place overgrown with briers and thorns./I will command the clouds/_to drop no rain on it.

17747.text: ¶The nation of Israel is the vineyard of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies./_The people of Judah are his pleasant garden./He expected a crop of justice,/_but instead he found oppression./He expected to find righteousness,/_but instead he heard cries of violence.

17748.text: §¶What sorrow for you who buy up house after house and field after field,/_until everyone is evicted and you live alone in the land.

17749.text: /But I have heard the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_swear a solemn oath:/“Many houses will stand deserted;/_even beautiful mansions will be empty.

17750.text: /Ten acres of vineyard will not produce even six gallons of wine./_Ten baskets of seed will yield only one basket of grain.”

17751.text: ¶What sorrow for those who get up early in the morning/_looking for a drink of alcohol/and spend long evenings drinking wine/_to make themselves flaming drunk.

17752.text: /They furnish wine and lovely music at their grand parties—/_lyre and harp, tambourine and flute—/but they never think about the Lord/_or notice what he is doing.

17753.text: ¶So my people will go into exile far away/_because they do not know me./Those who are great and honored will starve,/_and the common people will die of thirst.

17754.text: /The grave is licking its lips in anticipation,/_opening its mouth wide./The great and the lowly/_and all the drunken mob will be swallowed up.

17755.text: /Humanity will be destroyed, and people brought down;/_even the arrogant will lower their eyes in humiliation.

17756.text: /But the Lord of Heaven’s Armies will be exalted by his justice./_The holiness of God will be displayed by his righteousness.

17757.text: /In that day lambs will find good pastures,/_and fattened sheep and young goats will feed among the ruins.

17758.text: ¶What sorrow for those who drag their sins behind them/_with ropes made of lies,/_who drag wickedness behind them like a cart!

17759.text: /They even mock God and say,/_“Hurry up and do something!/_We want to see what you can do./Let the Holy One of Israel carry out his plan,/_for we want to know what it is.”

17760.text: ¶What sorrow for those who say/_that evil is good and good is evil,/that dark is light and light is dark,/_that bitter is sweet and sweet is bitter.

17761.text: /What sorrow for those who are wise in their own eyes/_and think themselves so clever.

17762.text: /What sorrow for those who are heroes at drinking wine/_and boast about all the alcohol they can hold.

17763.text: /They take bribes to let the wicked go free,/_and they punish the innocent.

17764.text: ¶Therefore, just as fire licks up stubble/_and dry grass shrivels in the flame,/so their roots will rot/_and their flowers wither./For they have rejected the law of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies;/_they have despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

17765.text: /That is why the Lord’s anger burns against his people,/_and why he has raised his fist to crush them./The mountains tremble,/_and the corpses of his people litter the streets like garbage./But even then the Lord’s anger is not satisfied./_His fist is still poised to strike!

17766.text: ¶He will send a signal to distant nations far away/_and whistle to those at the ends of the earth./_They will come racing toward Jerusalem.

17767.text: /They will not get tired or stumble./_They will not stop for rest or sleep./Not a belt will be loose,/_not a sandal strap broken.

17768.text: /Their arrows will be sharp/_and their bows ready for battle./Sparks will fly from their horses’ hooves,/_and the wheels of their chariots will spin like a whirlwind.

17769.text: /They will roar like lions,/_like the strongest of lions./Growling, they will pounce on their victims and carry them off,/_and no one will be there to rescue them.

17770.text: /They will roar over their victims on that day of destruction/_like the roaring of the sea./If someone looks across the land,/_only darkness and distress will be seen;/_even the light will be darkened by clouds.

17771.text: §¶It was in the year King Uzziah died that I saw the Lord. He was sitting on a lofty throne, and the train of his robe filled the Temple.

17772.text: Attending him were mighty seraphim, each having six wings. With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.

17773.text: They were calling out to each other,¶▼“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of Heaven’s Armies!/_The whole earth is filled with his glory!”

17774.text: ¶Their voices shook the Temple to its foundations, and the entire building was filled with smoke.

17775.text: ¶Then I said, “It’s all over! I am doomed, for I am a sinful man. I have filthy lips, and I live among a people with filthy lips. Yet I have seen the King, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.”

17776.text: ¶Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a burning coal he had taken from the altar with a pair of tongs.

17777.text: He touched my lips with it and said, “See, this coal has touched your lips. Now your guilt is removed, and your sins are forgiven.”

17778.text: ¶Then I heard the Lord asking, “Whom should I send as a messenger to this people? Who will go for us?”¶I said, “Here I am. Send me.”

17779.text: ¶And he said, “Yes, go, and say to this people,¶▼‘Listen carefully, but do not understand./_Watch closely, but learn nothing.’

17780.text: /Harden the hearts of these people./_Plug their ears and shut their eyes./That way, they will not see with their eyes,/_nor hear with their ears,/nor understand with their hearts/_and turn to me for healing.”

17781.text: ¶Then I said, “Lord, how long will this go on?”¶And he replied,¶▼“Until their towns are empty,/_their houses are deserted,/_and the whole country is a wasteland;

17782.text: /until the Lord has sent everyone away,/_and the entire land of Israel lies deserted.

17783.text: /If even a tenth—a remnant—survive,/_it will be invaded again and burned./But as a terebinth or oak tree leaves a stump when it is cut down,/_so Israel’s stump will be a holy seed.”

17784.text: §¶When Ahaz, son of Jotham and grandson of Uzziah, was king of Judah, King Rezin of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah, the king of Israel, set out to attack Jerusalem. However, they were unable to carry out their plan.

17785.text: ¶The news had come to the royal court of Judah: “Syria is allied with Israel against us!” So the hearts of the king and his people trembled with fear, like trees shaking in a storm.

17786.text: ¶Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Take your son Shear‐jashub and go out to meet King Ahaz. You will find him at the end of the aqueduct that feeds water into the upper pool, near the road leading to the field where cloth is washed.

17787.text: Tell him to stop worrying. Tell him he doesn’t need to fear the fierce anger of those two burned‐out embers, King Rezin of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah.

17788.text: Yes, the kings of Syria and Israel are plotting against him, saying,

17789.text: ‘We will attack Judah and capture it for ourselves. Then we will install the son of Tabeel as Judah’s king.’

17790.text: But this is what the Sovereign Lord says:¶▼“This invasion will never happen;/_it will never take place;

17791.text: /for Syria is no stronger than its capital, Damascus,/_and Damascus is no stronger than its king, Rezin./As for Israel, within sixty‐five years/_it will be crushed and completely destroyed.

17792.text: /Israel is no stronger than its capital, Samaria,/_and Samaria is no stronger than its king, Pekah son of Remaliah./Unless your faith is firm,/_I cannot make you stand firm.”

17793.text: §¶Later, the Lord sent this message to King Ahaz:

17794.text: “Ask the Lord your God for a sign of confirmation, Ahaz. Make it as difficult as you want—as high as heaven or as deep as the place of the dead.”

17795.text: ¶But the king refused. “No,” he said, “I will not test the Lord like that.”

17796.text: ¶Then Isaiah said, “Listen well, you royal family of David! Isn’t it enough to exhaust human patience? Must you exhaust the patience of my God as well?

17797.text: All right then, the Lord himself will give you the sign. Look! The virgin will conceive a child! She will give birth to a son and will call him Immanuel (which means ‘God is with us’).

17798.text: By the time this child is old enough to choose what is right and reject what is wrong, he will be eating yogurt and honey.

17799.text: For before the child is that old, the lands of the two kings you fear so much will both be deserted.

17800.text: ¶“Then the Lord will bring things on you, your nation, and your family unlike anything since Israel broke away from Judah. He will bring the king of Assyria upon you!”

17801.text: ¶In that day the Lord will whistle for the army of southern Egypt and for the army of Assyria. They will swarm around you like flies and bees.

17802.text: They will come in vast hordes and settle in the fertile areas and also in the desolate valleys, caves, and thorny places.

17803.text: In that day the Lord will hire a “razor” from beyond the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria—and use it to shave off everything: your land, your crops, and your people.

17804.text: ¶In that day a farmer will be fortunate to have a cow and two sheep or goats left.

17805.text: Nevertheless, there will be enough milk for everyone because so few people will be left in the land. They will eat their fill of yogurt and honey.

17806.text: In that day the lush vineyards, now worth 1,000 pieces of silver, will become patches of briers and thorns.

17807.text: The entire land will become a vast expanse of briers and thorns, a hunting ground overrun by wildlife.

17808.text: No one will go to the fertile hillsides where the gardens once grew, for briers and thorns will cover them. Cattle, sheep, and goats will graze there.

17809.text: §¶Then the Lord said to me, “Make a large signboard and clearly write this name on it: Maher‐shalal‐hash‐baz.”

17810.text: I asked Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberekiah, both known as honest men, to witness my doing this.

17811.text: ¶Then I slept with my wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. And the Lord said, “Call him Maher‐shalal‐hash‐baz.

17812.text: For before this child is old enough to say ‘Papa’ or ‘Mama,’ the king of Assyria will carry away both the abundance of Damascus and the riches of Samaria.”

17813.text: ¶Then the Lord spoke to me again and said,

17814.text: “My care for the people of Judah is like the gently flowing waters of Shiloah, but they have rejected it. They are rejoicing over what will happen to King Rezin and King Pekah.

17815.text: Therefore, the Lord will overwhelm them with a mighty flood from the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria and all his glory. This flood will overflow all its channels

17816.text: and sweep into Judah until it is chin deep. It will spread its wings, submerging your land from one end to the other, O Immanuel.

17817.text: ¶“Huddle together, you nations, and be terrified./_Listen, all you distant lands./Prepare for battle, but you will be crushed!/_Yes, prepare for battle, but you will be crushed!

17818.text: /Call your councils of war, but they will be worthless./_Develop your strategies, but they will not succeed./_For God is with us!”

17819.text: §¶The Lord has given me a strong warning not to think like everyone else does. He said,

17820.text: ¶“Don’t call everything a conspiracy, like they do,/_and don’t live in dread of what frightens them.

17821.text: /Make the Lord of Heaven’s Armies holy in your life./_He is the one you should fear./He is the one who should make you tremble.

17822.text: /_He will keep you safe./But to Israel and Judah/_he will be a stone that makes people stumble,/_a rock that makes them fall./And for the people of Jerusalem/_he will be a trap and a snare.

17823.text: /Many will stumble and fall,/_never to rise again./_They will be snared and captured.”

17824.text: ¶Preserve the teaching of God;/_entrust his instructions to those who follow me.

17825.text: /I will wait for the Lord,/_who has turned away from the descendants of Jacob./_I will put my hope in him.

17826.text: ¶I and the children the Lord has given me serve as signs and warnings to Israel from the Lord of Heaven’s Armies who dwells in his Temple on Mount Zion.

17827.text: ¶Someone may say to you, “Let’s ask the mediums and those who consult the spirits of the dead. With their whisperings and mutterings, they will tell us what to do.” But shouldn’t people ask God for guidance? Should the living seek guidance from the dead?

17828.text: ¶Look to God’s instructions and teachings! People who contradict his word are completely in the dark.

17829.text: They will go from one place to another, weary and hungry. And because they are hungry, they will rage and curse their king and their God. They will look up to heaven

17830.text: and down at the earth, but wherever they look, there will be trouble and anguish and dark despair. They will be thrown out into the darkness.

17831.text: §¶Nevertheless, that time of darkness and despair will not go on forever. The land of Zebulun and Naphtali will be humbled, but there will be a time in the future when Galilee of the Gentiles, which lies along the road that runs between the Jordan and the sea, will be filled with glory.

17832.text: ¶The people who walk in darkness/_will see a great light./For those who live in a land of deep darkness,/_a light will shine.

17833.text: /You will enlarge the nation of Israel,/_and its people will rejoice./They will rejoice before you/_as people rejoice at the harvest/_and like warriors dividing the plunder.

17834.text: /For you will break the yoke of their slavery/_and lift the heavy burden from their shoulders./You will break the oppressor’s rod,/_just as you did when you destroyed the army of Midian.

17835.text: /The boots of the warrior/_and the uniforms bloodstained by war/will all be burned./_They will be fuel for the fire.

17836.text: ¶For a child is born to us,/_a son is given to us./The government will rest on his shoulders./_And he will be called:/Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,/_Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.

17837.text: /His government and its peace/_will never end./He will rule with fairness and justice from the throne of his ancestor David/_for all eternity./The passionate commitment of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_will make this happen!

17838.text: §¶The Lord has spoken out against Jacob;/_his judgment has fallen upon Israel.

17839.text: /And the people of Israel and Samaria,/_who spoke with such pride and arrogance,/_will soon know it.

17840.text: /They said, “We will replace the broken bricks of our ruins with finished stone,/_and replant the felled sycamore‐fig trees with cedars.”

17841.text: ¶But the Lord will bring Rezin’s enemies against Israel/_and stir up all their foes.

17842.text: /The Syrians from the east and the Philistines from the west/_will bare their fangs and devour Israel./But even then the Lord’s anger will not be satisfied./_His fist is still poised to strike.

17843.text: ¶For after all this punishment, the people will still not repent./_They will not seek the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

17844.text: /Therefore, in a single day the Lord will destroy both the head and the tail,/_the noble palm branch and the lowly reed.

17845.text: /The leaders of Israel are the head,/_and the lying prophets are the tail.

17846.text: /For the leaders of the people have misled them./_They have led them down the path of destruction.

17847.text: /That is why the Lord takes no pleasure in the young men/_and shows no mercy even to the widows and orphans./For they are all wicked hypocrites,/_and they all speak foolishness./But even then the Lord’s anger will not be satisfied./_His fist is still poised to strike.

17848.text: ¶This wickedness is like a brushfire./_It burns not only briers and thorns/but also sets the forests ablaze./_Its burning sends up clouds of smoke.

17849.text: /The land will be blackened/_by the fury of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies./The people will be fuel for the fire,/_and no one will spare even his own brother.

17850.text: /They will attack their neighbor on the right/_but will still be hungry./They will devour their neighbor on the left/_but will not be satisfied./In the end they will even eat their own children.

17851.text: /Manasseh will feed on Ephraim,/_Ephraim will feed on Manasseh,/_and both will devour Judah./But even then the Lord’s anger will not be satisfied./_His fist is still poised to strike.

17852.text: ¶What sorrow awaits the unjust judges/_and those who issue unfair laws.

17853.text: /They deprive the poor of justice/_and deny the rights of the needy among my people./They prey on widows/_and take advantage of orphans.

17854.text: /What will you do when I punish you,/_when I send disaster upon you from a distant land?/To whom will you turn for help?/_Where will your treasures be safe?

17855.text: /You will stumble along as prisoners/_or lie among the dead./But even then the Lord’s anger will not be satisfied./_His fist is still poised to strike.

17856.text: §¶“What sorrow awaits Assyria, the rod of my anger./_I use it as a club to express my anger.

17857.text: /I am sending Assyria against a godless nation,/_against a people with whom I am angry./Assyria will plunder them,/_trampling them like dirt beneath its feet.

17858.text: /But the king of Assyria will not understand that he is my tool;/_his mind does not work that way./His plan is simply to destroy,/_to cut down nation after nation.

17859.text: /He will say,/_‘Each of my princes will soon be a king.

17860.text: /We destroyed Calno just as we did Carchemish./_Hamath fell before us as Arpad did./_And we destroyed Samaria just as we did Damascus.

17861.text: /Yes, we have finished off many a kingdom/_whose gods were greater than those in Jerusalem and Samaria.

17862.text: /So we will defeat Jerusalem and her gods,/_just as we destroyed Samaria with hers.’”

17863.text: ¶After the Lord has used the king of Assyria to accomplish his purposes on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, he will turn against the king of Assyria and punish him—for he is proud and arrogant.

17864.text: He boasts,¶▼“By my own powerful arm I have done this./_With my own shrewd wisdom I planned it./I have broken down the defenses of nations/_and carried off their treasures./_I have knocked down their kings like a bull.

17865.text: /I have robbed their nests of riches/_and gathered up kingdoms as a farmer gathers eggs./No one can even flap a wing against me/_or utter a peep of protest.”

17866.text: ¶But can the ax boast greater power than the person who uses it?/_Is the saw greater than the person who saws?/Can a rod strike unless a hand moves it?/_Can a wooden cane walk by itself?

17867.text: /Therefore, the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_will send a plague among Assyria’s proud troops,/_and a flaming fire will consume its glory.

17868.text: /The Lord, the Light of Israel, will be a fire;/_the Holy One will be a flame./He will devour the thorns and briers with fire,/_burning up the enemy in a single night.

17869.text: /The Lord will consume Assyria’s glory/_like a fire consumes a forest in a fruitful land;/_it will waste away like sick people in a plague.

17870.text: /Of all that glorious forest, only a few trees will survive—/_so few that a child could count them!

17871.text: §¶In that day the remnant left in Israel,/_the survivors in the house of Jacob,/will no longer depend on allies/_who seek to destroy them./But they will faithfully trust the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel.

17872.text: /A remnant will return;/_yes, the remnant of Jacob will return to the Mighty God.

17873.text: /But though the people of Israel are as numerous/_as the sand of the seashore,/only a remnant of them will return./_The Lord has rightly decided to destroy his people.

17874.text: /Yes, the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_has already decided to destroy the entire land.

17875.text: ¶So this is what the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, says: “O my people in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrians when they oppress you with rod and club as the Egyptians did long ago.

17876.text: In a little while my anger against you will end, and then my anger will rise up to destroy them.”

17877.text: The Lord of Heaven’s Armies will lash them with his whip, as he did when Gideon triumphed over the Midianites at the rock of Oreb, or when the Lord’s staff was raised to drown the Egyptian army in the sea.

17878.text: ¶In that day the Lord will end the bondage of his people./_He will break the yoke of slavery/_and lift it from their shoulders.

17879.text: ¶Look, the Assyrians are now at Aiath./_They are passing through Migron/_and are storing their equipment at Micmash.

17880.text: /They are crossing the pass/_and are camping at Geba./Fear strikes the town of Ramah./_All the people of Gibeah, the hometown of Saul,/_are running for their lives.

17881.text: /Scream in terror,/_you people of Gallim!/Shout out a warning to Laishah./_Oh, poor Anathoth!

17882.text: /There go the people of Madmenah, all fleeing./_The citizens of Gebim are trying to hide.

17883.text: /The enemy stops at Nob for the rest of that day./_He shakes his fist at beautiful Mount Zion, the mountain of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶But look! The Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_will chop down the mighty tree of Assyria with great power!/He will cut down the proud./_That lofty tree will be brought down.

17885.text: /He will cut down the forest trees with an ax./_Lebanon will fall to the Mighty One.

17886.text: §¶Out of the stump of David’s family will grow a shoot—/_yes, a new Branch bearing fruit from the old root.

17887.text: /And the Spirit of the Lord will rest on him—/_the Spirit of wisdom and understanding,/the Spirit of counsel and might,/_the Spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.

17888.text: /He will delight in obeying the Lord./_He will not judge by appearance/_nor make a decision based on hearsay.

17889.text: /He will give justice to the poor/_and make fair decisions for the exploited./The earth will shake at the force of his word,/_and one breath from his mouth will destroy the wicked.

17890.text: /He will wear righteousness like a belt/_and truth like an undergarment.

17891.text: ¶In that day the wolf and the lamb will live together;/_the leopard will lie down with the baby goat./The calf and the yearling will be safe with the lion,/_and a little child will lead them all.

17892.text: /The cow will graze near the bear./_The cub and the calf will lie down together./_The lion will eat hay like a cow.

17893.text: /The baby will play safely near the hole of a cobra./_Yes, a little child will put its hand in a nest of deadly snakes without harm.

17894.text: /Nothing will hurt or destroy in all my holy mountain,/_for as the waters fill the sea,/_so the earth will be filled with people who know the Lord.

17895.text: ¶In that day the heir to David’s throne/_will be a banner of salvation to all the world./The nations will rally to him,/_and the land where he lives will be a glorious place.

17896.text: /In that day the Lord will reach out his hand a second time/_to bring back the remnant of his people—/those who remain in Assyria and northern Egypt;/_in southern Egypt, Ethiopia, and Elam;/_in Babylonia, Hamath, and all the distant coastlands.

17897.text: /He will raise a flag among the nations/_and assemble the exiles of Israel./He will gather the scattered people of Judah/_from the ends of the earth.

17898.text: ¶Then at last the jealousy between Israel and Judah will end./_They will not be rivals anymore.

17899.text: /They will join forces to swoop down on Philistia to the west./_Together they will attack and plunder the nations to the east./They will occupy the lands of Edom and Moab,/_and Ammon will obey them.

17900.text: /The Lord will make a dry path through the gulf of the Red Sea./_He will wave his hand over the Euphrates River,/sending a mighty wind to divide it into seven streams/_so it can easily be crossed on foot.

17901.text: /He will make a highway for the remnant of his people,/_the remnant coming from Assyria,/just as he did for Israel long ago/_when they returned from Egypt.

17902.text: §¶In that day you will sing:/_“I will praise you, O Lord!/You were angry with me, but not any more./_Now you comfort me.

17903.text: /See, God has come to save me./_I will trust in him and not be afraid./The Lord God is my strength and my song;/_he has given me victory.”

17904.text: ¶With joy you will drink deeply/_from the fountain of salvation!

17905.text: /In that wonderful day you will sing:/_“Thank the Lord! Praise his name!/Tell the nations what he has done./_Let them know how mighty he is!

17906.text: /Sing to the Lord, for he has done wonderful things./_Make known his praise around the world.

17907.text: /Let all the people of Jerusalem shout his praise with joy!/_For great is the Holy One of Israel who lives among you.”

17908.text: §¶Isaiah son of Amoz received this message concerning the destruction of Babylon:

17909.text: ¶“Raise a signal flag on a bare hilltop./_Call up an army against Babylon./Wave your hand to encourage them/_as they march into the palaces of the high and mighty.

17910.text: /I, the Lord, have dedicated these soldiers for this task./_Yes, I have called mighty warriors to express my anger,/_and they will rejoice when I am exalted.”

17911.text: ¶Hear the noise on the mountains!/_Listen, as the vast armies march!/It is the noise and shouting of many nations./_The Lord of Heaven’s Armies has called this army together.

17912.text: /They come from distant countries,/_from beyond the farthest horizons./They are the Lord’s weapons to carry out his anger./_With them he will destroy the whole land.

17913.text: ¶Scream in terror, for the day of the Lord has arrived—/_the time for the Almighty to destroy.

17914.text: /Every arm is paralyzed with fear./_Every heart melts,

17915.text: /_and people are terrified./Pangs of anguish grip them,/_like those of a woman in labor./They look helplessly at one another,/_their faces aflame with fear.

17916.text: ¶For see, the day of the Lord is coming—/_the terrible day of his fury and fierce anger./The land will be made desolate,/_and all the sinners destroyed with it.

17917.text: /The heavens will be black above them;/_the stars will give no light./The sun will be dark when it rises,/_and the moon will provide no light.

17918.text: ¶“I, the Lord, will punish the world for its evil/_and the wicked for their sin./I will crush the arrogance of the proud/_and humble the pride of the mighty.

17919.text: /I will make people scarcer than gold—/_more rare than the fine gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /For I will shake the heavens./_The earth will move from its place/when the Lord of Heaven’s Armies displays his wrath/_in the day of his fierce anger.”

17921.text: ¶Everyone in Babylon will run about like a hunted gazelle,/_like sheep without a shepherd./They will try to find their own people/_and flee to their own land.

17922.text: /Anyone who is captured will be cut down—/_run through with a sword.

17923.text: /Their little children will be dashed to death before their eyes./_Their homes will be sacked, and their wives will be raped.

17924.text: ¶“Look, I will stir up the Medes against Babylon./_They cannot be tempted by silver/_or bribed with gold.

17925.text: /The attacking armies will shoot down the young men with arrows./_They will have no mercy on helpless babies/_and will show no compassion for children.”

17926.text: ¶Babylon, the most glorious of kingdoms,/_the flower of Chaldean pride,/will be devastated like Sodom and Gomorrah/_when God destroyed them.

17927.text: /Babylon will never be inhabited again./_It will remain empty for generation after generation./Nomads will refuse to camp there,/_and shepherds will not bed down their sheep.

17928.text: /Desert animals will move into the ruined city,/_and the houses will be haunted by howling creatures./Owls will live among the ruins,/_and wild goats will go there to dance.

17929.text: /Hyenas will howl in its fortresses,/_and jackals will make dens in its luxurious palaces./Babylon’s days are numbered;/_its time of destruction will soon arrive.

17930.text: §¶But the Lord will have mercy on the descendants of Jacob. He will choose Israel as his special people once again. He will bring them back to settle once again in their own land. And people from many different nations will come and join them there and unite with the people of Israel.

17931.text: The nations of the world will help the people of Israel to return, and those who come to live in the Lord’s land will serve them. Those who captured Israel will themselves be captured, and Israel will rule over its enemies.

17932.text: ¶In that wonderful day when the Lord gives his people rest from sorrow and fear, from slavery and chains,

17933.text: you will taunt the king of Babylon. You will say,¶▼“The mighty man has been destroyed./_Yes, your insolence is ended.

17934.text: /For the Lord has crushed your wicked power/_and broken your evil rule.

17935.text: /You struck the people with endless blows of rage/_and held the nations in your angry grip/_with unrelenting tyranny.

17936.text: /But finally the earth is at rest and quiet./_Now it can sing again!

17937.text: /Even the trees of the forest—/_the cypress trees and the cedars of Lebanon—/_sing out this joyous song:/‘Since you have been cut down,/_no one will come now to cut us down!’

17938.text: ¶“In the place of the dead there is excitement/_over your arrival./The spirits of world leaders and mighty kings long dead/_stand up to see you.

17939.text: /With one voice they all cry out,/_‘Now you are as weak as we are!

17940.text: /Your might and power were buried with you./_The sound of the harp in your palace has ceased./Now maggots are your sheet,/_and worms your blanket.’

17941.text: ¶“How you are fallen from heaven,/_O shining star, son of the morning!/You have been thrown down to the earth,/_you who destroyed the nations of the world.

17942.text: /For you said to yourself,/_‘I will ascend to heaven and set my throne above God’s stars./I will preside on the mountain of the gods/_far away in the north.

17943.text: /I will climb to the highest heavens/_and be like the Most High.’

17944.text: /Instead, you will be brought down to the place of the dead,/_down to its lowest depths.

17945.text: /Everyone there will stare at you and ask,/‘Can this be the one who shook the earth/_and made the kingdoms of the world tremble?

17946.text: /Is this the one who destroyed the world/_and made it into a wasteland?/Is this the king who demolished the world’s greatest cities/_and had no mercy on his prisoners?’

17947.text: ¶“The kings of the nations lie in stately glory,/_each in his own tomb,

17948.text: /but you will be thrown out of your grave/_like a worthless branch./Like a corpse trampled underfoot,/_you will be dumped into a mass grave/_with those killed in battle./You will descend to the pit.

17949.text: /_You will not be given a proper burial,/for you have destroyed your nation/_and slaughtered your people./The descendants of such an evil person/_will never again receive honor.

17950.text: /Kill this man’s children!/_Let them die because of their father’s sins!/They must not rise and conquer the earth,/_filling the world with their cities.”

17951.text: ¶This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies says:/_“I, myself, have risen against Babylon!/I will destroy its children and its children’s children,”/_says the Lord.

17952.text: /“I will make Babylon a desolate place of owls,/_filled with swamps and marshes./I will sweep the land with the broom of destruction./_I, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, have spoken!”

17953.text: §¶The Lord of Heaven’s Armies has sworn this oath:¶▼“It will all happen as I have planned./_It will be as I have decided.

17954.text: /I will break the Assyrians when they are in Israel;/_I will trample them on my mountains./My people will no longer be their slaves/_nor bow down under their heavy loads.

17955.text: /I have a plan for the whole earth,/_a hand of judgment upon all the nations.

17956.text: /The Lord of Heaven’s Armies has spoken—/_who can change his plans?/When his hand is raised,/_who can stop him?”

17957.text: §¶This message came to me the year King Ahaz died:

17958.text: ¶Do not rejoice, you Philistines,/_that the rod that struck you is broken—/_that the king who attacked you is dead./For from that snake a more poisonous snake will be born,/_a fiery serpent to destroy you!

17959.text: /I will feed the poor in my pasture;/_the needy will lie down in peace./But as for you, I will wipe you out with famine/_and destroy the few who remain.

17960.text: /Wail at the gates! Weep in the cities!/_Melt with fear, you Philistines!/A powerful army comes like smoke from the north./_Each soldier rushes forward eager to fight.

17961.text: ¶What should we tell the Philistine messengers? Tell them,¶▼“The Lord has built Jerusalem;/_its walls will give refuge to his oppressed people.”

17962.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Moab:¶▼In one night the town of Ar will be leveled,/_and the city of Kir will be destroyed.

17963.text: /Your people will go to their temple in Dibon to mourn./_They will go to their sacred shrines to weep./They will wail for the fate of Nebo and Medeba,/_shaving their heads in sorrow and cutting off their beards.

17964.text: /They will wear burlap as they wander the streets./_From every home and public square will come the sound of wailing.

17965.text: /The people of Heshbon and Elealeh will cry out;/_their voices will be heard as far away as Jahaz!/The bravest warriors of Moab will cry out in utter terror./_They will be helpless with fear.

17966.text: ¶My heart weeps for Moab./_Its people flee to Zoar and Eglath‐shelishiyah./Weeping, they climb the road to Luhith./_Their cries of distress can be heard all along the road to Horonaim.

17967.text: /Even the waters of Nimrim are dried up!/_The grassy banks are scorched./The tender plants are gone;/_nothing green remains.

17968.text: /The people grab their possessions/_and carry them across the Ravine of Willows.

17969.text: /A cry of distress echoes through the land of Moab/_from one end to the other—/_from Eglaim to Beer‐elim.

17970.text: /The stream near Dibon runs red with blood,/_but I am still not finished with Dibon!/Lions will hunt down the survivors—/_both those who try to escape/_and those who remain behind.

17971.text: ¶Send lambs from Sela as tribute/_to the ruler of the land./Send them through the desert/_to the mountain of beautiful Zion.

17972.text: /The women of Moab are left like homeless birds/_at the shallow crossings of the Arnon River.

17973.text: /“Help us,” they cry./_“Defend us against our enemies./Protect us from their relentless attack./_Do not betray us now that we have escaped.

17974.text: /Let our refugees stay among you./_Hide them from our enemies until the terror is past.”¶When oppression and destruction have ended/_and enemy raiders have disappeared,

17975.text: /then God will establish one of David’s descendants as king./_He will rule with mercy and truth./He will always do what is just/_and be eager to do what is right.

17976.text: ¶We have heard about proud Moab—/_about its pride and arrogance and rage./_But all that boasting has disappeared.

17977.text: /The entire land of Moab weeps./_Yes, everyone in Moab mourns/for the cakes of raisins from Kir‐hareseth./_They are all gone now.

17978.text: /The farms of Heshbon are abandoned;/_the vineyards at Sibmah are deserted./The rulers of the nations have broken down Moab—/_that beautiful grapevine./Its tendrils spread north as far as the town of Jazer/_and trailed eastward into the wilderness./Its shoots reached so far west/_that they crossed over the Dead Sea.

17979.text: ¶So now I weep for Jazer and the vineyards of Sibmah;/_my tears will flow for Heshbon and Elealeh./There are no more shouts of joy/_over your summer fruits and harvest.

17980.text: /Gone now is the gladness,/_gone the joy of harvest./There will be no singing in the vineyards,/_no more happy shouts,/no treading of grapes in the winepresses./_I have ended all their harvest joys.

17981.text: /My heart’s cry for Moab is like a lament on a harp./_I am filled with anguish for Kir‐hareseth.

17982.text: /The people of Moab will worship at their pagan shrines,/_but it will do them no good./They will cry to the gods in their temples,/_but no one will be able to save them.

17983.text: ¶The Lord has already said these things about Moab in the past.

17984.text: But now the Lord says, “Within three years, counting each day, the glory of Moab will be ended. From its great population, only a feeble few will be left alive.”

17985.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Damascus:¶▼“Look, the city of Damascus will disappear!/_It will become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: /The towns of Aroer will be deserted./_Flocks will graze in the streets and lie down undisturbed,/_with no one to chase them away.

17987.text: /The fortified towns of Israel will also be destroyed,/_and the royal power of Damascus will end./All that remains of Syria/_will share the fate of Israel’s departed glory,”/_declares the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

17988.text: ¶“In that day Israel’s glory will grow dim;/_its robust body will waste away.

17989.text: /The whole land will look like a grainfield/_after the harvesters have gathered the grain./It will be desolate,/_like the fields in the valley of Rephaim after the harvest.

17990.text: /Only a few of its people will be left,/_like stray olives left on a tree after the harvest./Only two or three remain in the highest branches,/_four or five scattered here and there on the limbs,”/_declares the Lord, the God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶Then at last the people will look to their Creator/_and turn their eyes to the Holy One of Israel.

17992.text: /They will no longer look to their idols for help/_or worship what their own hands have made./They will never again bow down to their Asherah poles/_or worship at the pagan shrines they have built.

17993.text: /Their largest cities will be like a deserted forest,/_like the land the Hivites and Amorites abandoned/when the Israelites came here so long ago./_It will be utterly desolate.

17994.text: /Why? Because you have turned from the God who can save you./_You have forgotten the Rock who can hide you./So you may plant the finest grapevines/_and import the most expensive seedlings.

17995.text: /They may sprout on the day you set them out;/_yes, they may blossom on the very morning you plant them,/but you will never pick any grapes from them./_Your only harvest will be a load of grief and unrelieved pain.

17996.text: ¶Listen! The armies of many nations/_roar like the roaring of the sea./Hear the thunder of the mighty forces/_as they rush forward like thundering waves.

17997.text: /But though they thunder like breakers on a beach,/_God will silence them, and they will run away./They will flee like chaff scattered by the wind,/_like a tumbleweed whirling before a storm.

17998.text: /In the evening Israel waits in terror,/_but by dawn its enemies are dead./This is the just reward of those who plunder us,/_a fitting end for those who destroy us.

17999.text: §¶Listen, Ethiopia—land of fluttering sails/_that lies at the headwaters of the Nile,

18000.text: /that sends ambassadors/_in swift boats down the river.¶Go, swift messengers!/Take a message to a tall, smooth‐skinned people,/_who are feared far and wide/for their conquests and destruction,/_and whose land is divided by rivers.

18001.text: ¶All you people of the world,/_everyone who lives on the earth—/when I raise my battle flag on the mountain, look!/_When I blow the ram’s horn, listen!

18002.text: /For the Lord has told me this:/“I will watch quietly from my dwelling place—/_as quietly as the heat rises on a summer day,/_or as the morning dew forms during the harvest.”

18003.text: /Even before you begin your attack,/_while your plans are ripening like grapes,/the Lord will cut off your new growth with pruning shears./_He will snip off and discard your spreading branches.

18004.text: /Your mighty army will be left dead in the fields/_for the mountain vultures and wild animals./The vultures will tear at the corpses all summer./_The wild animals will gnaw at the bones all winter.

18005.text: ¶At that time the Lord of Heaven’s Armies will receive gifts/_from this land divided by rivers,/from this tall, smooth‐skinned people,/_who are feared far and wide for their conquests and destruction./They will bring the gifts to Jerusalem,/_where the Lord of Heaven’s Armies dwells.

18006.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Egypt:¶▼Look! The Lord is advancing against Egypt,/_riding on a swift cloud./The idols of Egypt tremble./_The hearts of the Egyptians melt with fear.

18007.text: ¶“I will make Egyptian fight against Egyptian—/_brother against brother,/neighbor against neighbor,/_city against city,/_province against province.

18008.text: /The Egyptians will lose heart,/_and I will confuse their plans./They will plead with their idols for wisdom/_and call on spirits, mediums, and those who consult the spirits of the dead.

18009.text: /I will hand Egypt over/_to a hard, cruel master./A fierce king will rule them,”/_says the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

18010.text: ¶The waters of the Nile will fail to rise and flood the fields./_The riverbed will be parched and dry.

18011.text: /The canals of the Nile will dry up,/_and the streams of Egypt will stink/_with rotting reeds and rushes.

18012.text: /All the greenery along the riverbank/_and all the crops along the river/_will dry up and blow away.

18013.text: /The fishermen will lament for lack of work./_Those who cast hooks into the Nile will groan,/_and those who use nets will lose heart.

18014.text: /There will be no flax for the harvesters,/_no thread for the weavers.

18015.text: /They will be in despair,/_and all the workers will be sick at heart.

18016.text: ¶What fools are the officials of Zoan!/_Their best counsel to the king of Egypt is stupid and wrong./Will they still boast to Pharaoh of their wisdom?/_Will they dare brag about all their wise ancestors?

18017.text: /Where are your wise counselors, Pharaoh?/_Let them tell you what God plans,/_what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies is going to do to Egypt.

18018.text: /The officials of Zoan are fools,/_and the officials of Memphis are deluded./The leaders of the people/_have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /The Lord has sent a spirit of foolishness on them,/_so all their suggestions are wrong./They cause Egypt to stagger/_like a drunk in his vomit.

18020.text: /There is nothing Egypt can do./_All are helpless—/the head and the tail,/_the noble palm branch and the lowly reed.

18021.text: ¶In that day the Egyptians will be as weak as women. They will cower in fear beneath the upraised fist of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

18022.text: Just to speak the name of Israel will terrorize them, for the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has laid out his plans against them.

18023.text: ¶In that day five of Egypt’s cities will follow the Lord of Heaven’s Armies. They will even begin to speak Hebrew, the language of Canaan. One of these cities will be Heliopolis, the City of the Sun.

18024.text: ¶In that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the heart of Egypt, and there will be a monument to the Lord at its border.

18025.text: It will be a sign and a witness that the Lord of Heaven’s Armies is worshiped in the land of Egypt. When the people cry to the Lord for help against those who oppress them, he will send them a savior who will rescue them.

18026.text: The Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians. Yes, they will know the Lord and will give their sacrifices and offerings to him. They will make a vow to the Lord and will keep it.

18027.text: The Lord will strike Egypt, and then he will bring healing. For the Egyptians will turn to the Lord, and he will listen to their pleas and heal them.

18028.text: ¶In that day Egypt and Assyria will be connected by a highway. The Egyptians and Assyrians will move freely between their lands, and they will both worship God.

18029.text: In that day Israel will be the third, along with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth.

18030.text: For the Lord of Heaven’s Armies will say, “Blessed be Egypt, my people. Blessed be Assyria, the land I have made. Blessed be Israel, my special possession!”

18031.text: §¶In the year when King Sargon of Assyria sent his commander in chief to capture the Philistine city of Ashdod,

18032.text: the Lord told Isaiah son of Amoz, “Take off the burlap you have been wearing, and remove your sandals.” Isaiah did as he was told and walked around naked and barefoot.

18033.text: ¶Then the Lord said, “My servant Isaiah has been walking around naked and barefoot for the last three years. This is a sign—a symbol of the terrible troubles I will bring upon Egypt and Ethiopia.

18034.text: For the king of Assyria will take away the Egyptians and Ethiopians as prisoners. He will make them walk naked and barefoot, both young and old, their buttocks bared, to the shame of Egypt.

18035.text: Then the Philistines will be thrown into panic, for they counted on the power of Ethiopia and boasted of their allies in Egypt!

18036.text: They will say, ‘If this can happen to Egypt, what chance do we have? We were counting on Egypt to protect us from the king of Assyria.’”

18037.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Babylon—the desert by the sea:¶▼Disaster is roaring down on you from the desert,/_like a whirlwind sweeping in from the Negev.

18038.text: /I see a terrifying vision:/_I see the betrayer betraying,/_the destroyer destroying./Go ahead, you Elamites and Medes,/_attack and lay siege./I will make an end/_to all the groaning Babylon caused.

18039.text: /My stomach aches and burns with pain./_Sharp pangs of anguish are upon me,/_like those of a woman in labor./I grow faint when I hear what God is planning;/_I am too afraid to look.

18040.text: /My mind reels and my heart races./_I longed for evening to come,/_but now I am terrified of the dark.

18041.text: ¶Look! They are preparing a great feast./_They are spreading rugs for people to sit on./_Everyone is eating and drinking./But quick! Grab your shields and prepare for battle./_You are being attacked!

18042.text: ¶Meanwhile, the Lord said to me,/“Put a watchman on the city wall./_Let him shout out what he sees.

18043.text: /He should look for chariots/_drawn by pairs of horses,/and for riders on donkeys and camels./_Let the watchman be fully alert.”

18044.text: ¶Then the watchman called out,/“Day after day I have stood on the watchtower, my lord./_Night after night I have remained at my post.

18045.text: /Now at last—look!/Here comes a man in a chariot/_with a pair of horses!”/Then the watchman said,/_“Babylon is fallen, fallen!/All the idols of Babylon/_lie broken on the ground!”

18046.text: /O my people, threshed and winnowed,/_I have told you everything the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has said,/_everything the God of Israel has told me.

18047.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Edom:¶▼Someone from Edom keeps calling to me,/“Watchman, how much longer until morning?/_When will the night be over?”

18048.text: /The watchman replies,/“Morning is coming, but night will soon return./_If you wish to ask again, then come back and ask.”

18049.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Arabia:¶▼O caravans from Dedan,/_hide in the deserts of Arabia.

18050.text: /O people of Tema,/_bring water to these thirsty people,/_food to these weary refugees.

18051.text: /They have fled from the sword,/_from the drawn sword,/from the bent bow/_and the terrors of battle.

18052.text: ¶The Lord said to me, “Within a year, counting each day, all the glory of Kedar will come to an end.

18053.text: Only a few of its courageous archers will survive. I, the Lord, the God of Israel, have spoken!”

18054.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Jerusalem—the Valley of Vision:¶▼What is happening?/_Why is everyone running to the rooftops?

18055.text: /The whole city is in a terrible uproar./_What do I see in this reveling city?/Bodies are lying everywhere,/_killed not in battle but by famine and disease.

18056.text: /All your leaders have fled./_They surrendered without resistance./The people tried to slip away,/_but they were captured, too.

18057.text: /That’s why I said, “Leave me alone to weep;/_do not try to comfort me./Let me cry for my people/_as I watch them being destroyed.”

18058.text: ¶Oh, what a day of crushing defeat!/_What a day of confusion and terror/brought by the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_upon the Valley of Vision!/The walls of Jerusalem have been broken,/_and cries of death echo from the mountainsides.

18059.text: /Elamites are the archers,/_with their chariots and charioteers./_The men of Kir hold up the shields.

18060.text: /Chariots fill your beautiful valleys,/_and charioteers storm your gates.

18061.text: /Judah’s defenses have been stripped away./_You run to the armory for your weapons.

18062.text: /You inspect the breaks in the walls of Jerusalem./_You store up water in the lower pool.

18063.text: /You survey the houses and tear some down/_for stone to strengthen the walls.

18064.text: /Between the city walls, you build a reservoir/_for water from the old pool./But you never ask for help from the One who did all this./_You never considered the One who planned this long ago.

18065.text: ¶At that time the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_called you to weep and mourn./He told you to shave your heads in sorrow for your sins/_and to wear clothes of burlap to show your remorse.

18066.text: /But instead, you dance and play;/_you slaughter cattle and kill sheep./_You feast on meat and drink wine./You say, “Let’s feast and drink,/_for tomorrow we die!”

18067.text: ¶The Lord of Heaven’s Armies has revealed this to me: “Till the day you die, you will never be forgiven for this sin.” That is the judgment of the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

18068.text: §¶This is what the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, said to me: “Confront Shebna, the palace administrator, and give him this message:

18069.text: ¶“Who do you think you are,/_and what are you doing here,/building a beautiful tomb for yourself—/_a monument high up in the rock?

18070.text: /For the Lord is about to hurl you away, mighty man./_He is going to grab you,

18071.text: /crumple you into a ball,/_and toss you away into a distant, barren land./There you will die,/_and your glorious chariots will be broken and useless./_You are a disgrace to your master!

18072.text: ¶“Yes, I will drive you out of office,” says the Lord. “I will pull you down from your high position.

18073.text: And then I will call my servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah to replace you.

18074.text: I will dress him in your royal robes and will give him your title and your authority. And he will be a father to the people of Jerusalem and Judah.

18075.text: I will give him the key to the house of David—the highest position in the royal court. When he opens doors, no one will be able to close them; when he closes doors, no one will be able to open them.

18076.text: He will bring honor to his family name, for I will drive him firmly in place like a nail in the wall.

18077.text: They will give him great responsibility, and he will bring honor to even the lowliest members of his family.”

18078.text: ¶But the Lord of Heaven’s Armies also says: “The time will come when I will pull out the nail that seemed so firm. It will come out and fall to the ground. Everything it supports will fall with it. I, the Lord, have spoken!”

18079.text: §¶This message came to me concerning Tyre:¶▼Wail, you trading ships of Tarshish,/_for the harbor and houses of Tyre are gone!/The rumors you heard in Cyprus/_are all true.

18080.text: /Mourn in silence, you people of the coast/_and you merchants of Sidon./Your traders crossed the sea,

18081.text: /_sailing over deep waters./They brought you grain from Egypt/_and harvests from along the Nile./You were the marketplace of the world.

18082.text: ¶But now you are put to shame, city of Sidon,/_for Tyre, the fortress of the sea, says,/“Now I am childless;/_I have no sons or daughters.”

18083.text: /When Egypt hears the news about Tyre,/_there will be great sorrow.

18084.text: /Send word now to Tarshish!/_Wail, you people who live in distant lands!

18085.text: /Is this silent ruin all that is left of your once joyous city?/_What a long history was yours!/_Think of all the colonists you sent to distant places.

18086.text: ¶Who has brought this disaster on Tyre,/_that great creator of kingdoms?/Her traders were all princes,/_her merchants were nobles.

18087.text: /The Lord of Heaven’s Armies has done it/_to destroy your pride/_and bring low all earth’s nobility.

18088.text: /Come, people of Tarshish,/_sweep over the land like the flooding Nile,/_for Tyre is defenseless.

18089.text: /The Lord held out his hand over the sea/_and shook the kingdoms of the earth./He has spoken out against Phoenicia,/_ordering that her fortresses be destroyed.

18090.text: /He says, “Never again will you rejoice,/_O daughter of Sidon, for you have been crushed./Even if you flee to Cyprus,/_you will find no rest.”

18091.text: ¶Look at the land of Babylonia—/_the people of that land are gone!/The Assyrians have handed Babylon over/_to the wild animals of the desert./They have built siege ramps against its walls,/_torn down its palaces,/_and turned it to a heap of rubble.

18092.text: ¶Wail, you ships of Tarshish,/_for your harbor is destroyed!

18093.text: ¶For seventy years, the length of a king’s life, Tyre will be forgotten. But then the city will come back to life as in the song about the prostitute:

18094.text: ¶Take a harp and walk the streets,/_you forgotten harlot./Make sweet melody and sing your songs/_so you will be remembered again.

18095.text: ¶Yes, after seventy years the Lord will revive Tyre. But she will be no different than she was before. She will again be a prostitute to all kingdoms around the world.

18096.text: But in the end her profits will be given to the Lord. Her wealth will not be hoarded but will provide good food and fine clothing for the Lord’s priests.

18097.text: §¶Look! The Lord is about to destroy the earth/_and make it a vast wasteland./He devastates the surface of the earth/_and scatters the people.

18098.text: /Priests and laypeople,/_servants and masters,/_maids and mistresses,/_buyers and sellers,/_lenders and borrowers,/_bankers and debtors—none will be spared.

18099.text: /The earth will be completely emptied and looted./_The Lord has spoken!

18100.text: ¶The earth mourns and dries up,/_and the land wastes away and withers./_Even the greatest people on earth waste away.

18101.text: /The earth suffers for the sins of its people,/_for they have twisted God’s instructions,/violated his laws,/_and broken his everlasting covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore, a curse consumes the earth./_Its people must pay the price for their sin./They are destroyed by fire,/_and only a few are left alive.

18103.text: /The grapevines waste away,/_and there is no new wine./_All the merrymakers sigh and mourn.

18104.text: /The cheerful sound of tambourines is stilled;/_the happy cries of celebration are heard no more./_The melodious chords of the harp are silent.

18105.text: /Gone are the joys of wine and song;/_alcoholic drink turns bitter in the mouth.

18106.text: /The city writhes in chaos;/_every home is locked to keep out intruders.

18107.text: /Mobs gather in the streets, crying out for wine./_Joy has turned to gloom./_Gladness has been banished from the land.

18108.text: /The city is left in ruins,/_its gates battered down.

18109.text: /Throughout the earth the story is the same—/_only a remnant is left,/like the stray olives left on the tree/_or the few grapes left on the vine after harvest.

18110.text: ¶But all who are left shout and sing for joy./_Those in the west praise the Lord’s majesty.

18111.text: /In eastern lands, give glory to the Lord./_In the lands beyond the sea, praise the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.

18112.text: /We hear songs of praise from the ends of the earth,/_songs that give glory to the Righteous One!¶But my heart is heavy with grief./_Weep for me, for I wither away./Deceit still prevails,/_and treachery is everywhere.

18113.text: /Terror and traps and snares will be your lot,/_you people of the earth.

18114.text: /Those who flee in terror will fall into a trap,/_and those who escape the trap will be caught in a snare.¶Destruction falls like rain from the heavens;/_the foundations of the earth shake.

18115.text: /The earth has broken up./_It has utterly collapsed;/_it is violently shaken.

18116.text: /The earth staggers like a drunk./_It trembles like a tent in a storm./It falls and will not rise again,/_for the guilt of its rebellion is very heavy.

18117.text: ¶In that day the Lord will punish the gods in the heavens/_and the proud rulers of the nations on earth.

18118.text: /They will be rounded up and put in prison./_They will be shut up in prison/_and will finally be punished.

18119.text: /Then the glory of the moon will wane,/_and the brightness of the sun will fade,/for the Lord of Heaven’s Armies will rule on Mount Zion./_He will rule in great glory in Jerusalem,/_in the sight of all the leaders of his people.

18120.text: §¶O Lord, I will honor and praise your name,/_for you are my God./You do such wonderful things!/_You planned them long ago,/_and now you have accomplished them.

18121.text: /You turn mighty cities into heaps of ruins./_Cities with strong walls are turned to rubble./Beautiful palaces in distant lands disappear/_and will never be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Therefore, strong nations will declare your glory;/_ruthless nations will fear you.

18123.text: ¶But you are a tower of refuge to the poor, O Lord,/_a tower of refuge to the needy in distress./You are a refuge from the storm/_and a shelter from the heat./For the oppressive acts of ruthless people/_are like a storm beating against a wall,

18124.text: /_or like the relentless heat of the desert./But you silence the roar of foreign nations./_As the shade of a cloud cools relentless heat,/_so the boastful songs of ruthless people are stilled.

18125.text: ¶In Jerusalem, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_will spread a wonderful feast/_for all the people of the world./It will be a delicious banquet/_with clear, well‐aged wine and choice meat.

18126.text: /There he will remove the cloud of gloom,/_the shadow of death that hangs over the earth.

18127.text: /He will swallow up death forever!/_The Sovereign Lord will wipe away all tears./He will remove forever all insults and mockery/_against his land and people./_The Lord has spoken!

18128.text: ¶In that day the people will proclaim,/“This is our God!/_We trusted in him, and he saved us!/This is the Lord, in whom we trusted./_Let us rejoice in the salvation he brings!”

18129.text: /For the Lord’s hand of blessing will rest on Jerusalem./_But Moab will be crushed./_It will be like straw trampled down and left to rot.

18130.text: /God will push down Moab’s people/_as a swimmer pushes down water with his hands./He will end their pride/_and all their evil works.

18131.text: /The high walls of Moab will be demolished./_They will be brought down to the ground,/_down into the dust.

18132.text: §¶In that day, everyone in the land of Judah will sing this song:¶▼Our city is strong!/_We are surrounded by the walls of God’s salvation.

18133.text: /Open the gates to all who are righteous;/_allow the faithful to enter.

18134.text: /You will keep in perfect peace/_all who trust in you,/_all whose thoughts are fixed on you!

18135.text: /Trust in the Lord always,/_for the Lord God is the eternal Rock.

18136.text: /He humbles the proud/_and brings down the arrogant city./_He brings it down to the dust.

18137.text: /The poor and oppressed trample it underfoot,/_and the needy walk all over it.

18138.text: ¶But for those who are righteous,/_the way is not steep and rough./You are a God who does what is right,/_and you smooth out the path ahead of them.

18139.text: /Lord, we show our trust in you by obeying your laws;/_our heart’s desire is to glorify your name.

18140.text: /In the night I search for you;/_in the morning I earnestly seek you./For only when you come to judge the earth/_will people learn what is right.

18141.text: /Your kindness to the wicked/_does not make them do good./Although others do right, the wicked keep doing wrong/_and take no notice of the Lord’s majesty.

18142.text: /O Lord, they pay no attention to your upraised fist./_Show them your eagerness to defend your people./Then they will be ashamed./_Let your fire consume your enemies.

18143.text: ¶Lord, you will grant us peace;/_all we have accomplished is really from you.

18144.text: /O Lord our God, others have ruled us,/_but you alone are the one we worship.

18145.text: /Those we served before are dead and gone./_Their departed spirits will never return!/You attacked them and destroyed them,/_and they are long forgotten.

18146.text: /O Lord, you have made our nation great;/_yes, you have made us great./You have extended our borders,/_and we give you the glory!

18147.text: ¶Lord, in distress we searched for you./_We prayed beneath the burden of your discipline.

18148.text: /Just as a pregnant woman/_writhes and cries out in pain as she gives birth,/_so were we in your presence, Lord.

18149.text: /We, too, writhe in agony,/_but nothing comes of our suffering./We have not given salvation to the earth,/_nor brought life into the world.

18150.text: /But those who die in the Lord will live;/_their bodies will rise again!/Those who sleep in the earth/_will rise up and sing for joy!/For your life‐giving light will fall like dew/_on your people in the place of the dead!

18151.text: §¶Go home, my people,/_and lock your doors!/Hide yourselves for a little while/_until the Lord’s anger has passed.

18152.text: /Look! The Lord is coming from heaven/_to punish the people of the earth for their sins./The earth will no longer hide those who have been killed./_They will be brought out for all to see.

18153.text: ¶In that day the Lord will take his terrible, swift sword and punish Leviathan, the swiftly moving serpent, the coiling, writhing serpent. He will kill the dragon of the sea.

18154.text: ¶“In that day,/_sing about the fruitful vineyard.

18155.text: /I, the Lord, will watch over it,/_watering it carefully./Day and night I will watch so no one can harm it.

18156.text: /_My anger will be gone./If I find briers and thorns growing,/_I will attack them;/I will burn them up—

18157.text: /_unless they turn to me for help./Let them make peace with me;/_yes, let them make peace with me.”

18158.text: /The time is coming when Jacob’s descendants will take root./_Israel will bud and blossom/_and fill the whole earth with fruit!

18159.text: ¶Has the Lord struck Israel/_as he struck her enemies?/Has he punished her/_as he punished them?

18160.text: /No, but he exiled Israel to call her to account./_She was exiled from her land/_as though blown away in a storm from the east.

18161.text: /The Lord did this to purge Israel’s wickedness,/_to take away all her sin./As a result, all the pagan altars will be crushed to dust./_No Asherah pole or pagan shrine will be left standing.

18162.text: /The fortified towns will be silent and empty,/_the houses abandoned, the streets overgrown with weeds./Calves will graze there,/_chewing on twigs and branches.

18163.text: /The people are like the dead branches of a tree,/_broken off and used for kindling beneath the cooking pots./Israel is a foolish and stupid nation,/_for its people have turned away from God./Therefore, the one who made them/_will show them no pity or mercy.

18164.text: ¶Yet the time will come when the Lord will gather them together like handpicked grain. One by one he will gather them—from the Euphrates River in the east to the Brook of Egypt in the west.

18165.text: In that day the great trumpet will sound. Many who were dying in exile in Assyria and Egypt will return to Jerusalem to worship the Lord on his holy mountain.

18166.text: §¶What sorrow awaits the proud city of Samaria—/_the glorious crown of the drunks of Israel./It sits at the head of a fertile valley,/_but its glorious beauty will fade like a flower./It is the pride of a people/_brought down by wine.

18167.text: /For the Lord will send a mighty army against it./_Like a mighty hailstorm and a torrential rain,/they will burst upon it like a surging flood/_and smash it to the ground.

18168.text: /The proud city of Samaria—/_the glorious crown of the drunks of Israel—/_will be trampled beneath its enemies’ feet.

18169.text: /It sits at the head of a fertile valley,/_but its glorious beauty will fade like a flower./Whoever sees it will snatch it up,/_as an early fig is quickly picked and eaten.

18170.text: ¶Then at last the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_will himself be Israel’s glorious crown./He will be the pride and joy/_of the remnant of his people.

18171.text: /He will give a longing for justice/_to their judges./He will give great courage/_to their warriors who stand at the gates.

18172.text: ¶Now, however, Israel is led by drunks/_who reel with wine and stagger with alcohol./The priests and prophets stagger with alcohol/_and lose themselves in wine./They reel when they see visions/_and stagger as they render decisions.

18173.text: /Their tables are covered with vomit;/_filth is everywhere.

18174.text: /“Who does the Lord think we are?” they ask./_“Why does he speak to us like this?/Are we little children,/_just recently weaned?

18175.text: /He tells us everything over and over—/one line at a time,/_one line at a time,/a little here,/_and a little there!”

18176.text: ¶So now God will have to speak to his people/_through foreign oppressors who speak a strange language!

18177.text: /God has told his people,/“Here is a place of rest;/_let the weary rest here./This is a place of quiet rest.”/_But they would not listen.

18178.text: /So the Lord will spell out his message for them again,/one line at a time,/_one line at a time,/a little here,/_and a little there,/so that they will stumble and fall./_They will be injured, trapped, and captured.

18179.text: ¶Therefore, listen to this message from the Lord,/_you scoffing rulers in Jerusalem.

18180.text: /You boast, “We have struck a bargain to cheat death/_and have made a deal to dodge the grave./The coming destruction can never touch us,/_for we have built a strong refuge made of lies and deception.”
