18181.text: ¶Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says:/“Look! I am placing a foundation stone in Jerusalem,/_a firm and tested stone./It is a precious cornerstone that is safe to build on./_Whoever believes need never be shaken.

18182.text: /I will test you with the measuring line of justice/_and the plumb line of righteousness./Since your refuge is made of lies,/_a hailstorm will knock it down./Since it is made of deception,/_a flood will sweep it away.

18183.text: /I will cancel the bargain you made to cheat death,/_and I will overturn your deal to dodge the grave./When the terrible enemy sweeps through,/_you will be trampled into the ground.

18184.text: /Again and again that flood will come,/_morning after morning,/day and night,/_until you are carried away.”¶This message will bring terror to your people.

18185.text: /The bed you have made is too short to lie on./_The blankets are too narrow to cover you.

18186.text: /The Lord will come as he did against the Philistines at Mount Perazim/_and against the Amorites at Gibeon./He will come to do a strange thing;/_he will come to do an unusual deed:

18187.text: /For the Lord, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_has plainly said that he is determined to crush the whole land./So scoff no more,/_or your punishment will be even greater.

18188.text: ¶Listen to me;/_listen, and pay close attention.

18189.text: /Does a farmer always plow and never sow?/_Is he forever cultivating the soil and never planting?

18190.text: /Does he not finally plant his seeds—/_black cumin, cumin, wheat, barley, and emmer wheat—/each in its proper way,/_and each in its proper place?

18191.text: /The farmer knows just what to do,/_for God has given him understanding.

18192.text: /A heavy sledge is never used to thresh black cumin;/_rather, it is beaten with a light stick./A threshing wheel is never rolled on cumin;/_instead, it is beaten lightly with a flail.

18193.text: /Grain for bread is easily crushed,/_so he doesn’t keep on pounding it./He threshes it under the wheels of a cart,/_but he doesn’t pulverize it.

18194.text: /The Lord of Heaven’s Armies is a wonderful teacher,/_and he gives the farmer great wisdom.

18195.text: §¶“What sorrow awaits Ariel, the City of David./_Year after year you celebrate your feasts.

18196.text: /Yet I will bring disaster upon you,/_and there will be much weeping and sorrow./For Jerusalem will become what her name Ariel means—/_an altar covered with blood.

18197.text: /I will be your enemy,/_surrounding Jerusalem and attacking its walls./I will build siege towers/_and destroy it.

18198.text: /Then deep from the earth you will speak;/_from low in the dust your words will come./Your voice will whisper from the ground/_like a ghost conjured up from the grave.

18199.text: ¶“But suddenly, your ruthless enemies will be crushed/_like the finest of dust./Your many attackers will be driven away/_like chaff before the wind./Suddenly, in an instant,

18200.text: /_I, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, will act for you/with thunder and earthquake and great noise,/_with whirlwind and storm and consuming fire.

18201.text: /All the nations fighting against Jerusalem/_will vanish like a dream!/Those who are attacking her walls/_will vanish like a vision in the night.

18202.text: /A hungry person dreams of eating/_but wakes up still hungry./A thirsty person dreams of drinking/_but is still faint from thirst when morning comes./So it will be with your enemies,/_with those who attack Mount Zion.”

18203.text: ¶Are you amazed and incredulous?/_Don’t you believe it?/Then go ahead and be blind./_You are stupid, but not from wine!/_You stagger, but not from liquor!

18204.text: /For the Lord has poured out on you a spirit of deep sleep./_He has closed the eyes of your prophets and visionaries.

18205.text: ¶All the future events in this vision are like a sealed book to them. When you give it to those who can read, they will say, “We can’t read it because it is sealed.”

18206.text: When you give it to those who cannot read, they will say, “We don’t know how to read.”

18207.text: ¶And so the Lord says,/_“These people say they are mine./They honor me with their lips,/_but their hearts are far from me./And their worship of me/_is nothing but man‐made rules learned by rote.

18208.text: /Because of this, I will once again astound these hypocrites/_with amazing wonders./The wisdom of the wise will pass away,/_and the intelligence of the intelligent will disappear.”

18209.text: ¶What sorrow awaits those who try to hide their plans from the Lord,/_who do their evil deeds in the dark!/“The Lord can’t see us,” they say./_“He doesn’t know what’s going on!”

18210.text: /How foolish can you be?/_He is the Potter, and he is certainly greater than you, the clay!/Should the created thing say of the one who made it,/_“He didn’t make me”?/Does a jar ever say,/_“The potter who made me is stupid”?

18211.text: ¶Soon—and it will not be very long—/_the forests of Lebanon will become a fertile field,/_and the fertile field will yield bountiful crops.

18212.text: /In that day the deaf will hear words read from a book,/_and the blind will see through the gloom and darkness.

18213.text: /The humble will be filled with fresh joy from the Lord./_The poor will rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.

18214.text: /The scoffer will be gone,/_the arrogant will disappear,/_and those who plot evil will be killed.

18215.text: /Those who convict the innocent/_by their false testimony will disappear./A similar fate awaits those who use trickery to pervert justice/_and who tell lies to destroy the innocent.

18216.text: ¶That is why the Lord, who redeemed Abraham, says to the people of Israel,¶▼“My people will no longer be ashamed/_or turn pale with fear.

18217.text: /For when they see their many children/_and all the blessings I have given them,/they will recognize the holiness of the Holy One of Jacob./_They will stand in awe of the God of Israel.

18218.text: /Then the wayward will gain understanding,/_and complainers will accept instruction.

18219.text: §¶“What sorrow awaits my rebellious children,”/_says the Lord./“You make plans that are contrary to mine./_You make alliances not directed by my Spirit,/_thus piling up your sins.

18220.text: /For without consulting me,/_you have gone down to Egypt for help./You have put your trust in Pharaoh’s protection./_You have tried to hide in his shade.

18221.text: /But by trusting Pharaoh, you will be humiliated,/_and by depending on him, you will be disgraced.

18222.text: /For though his power extends to Zoan/_and his officials have arrived in Hanes,

18223.text: /all who trust in him will be ashamed./_He will not help you./_Instead, he will disgrace you.”

18224.text: ¶This message came to me concerning the animals in the Negev:¶▼The caravan moves slowly/_across the terrible desert to Egypt—/donkeys weighed down with riches/_and camels loaded with treasure—/_all to pay for Egypt’s protection./They travel through the wilderness,/_a place of lionesses and lions,/_a place where vipers and poisonous snakes live./All this, and Egypt will give you nothing in return.

18225.text: /_Egypt’s promises are worthless!/Therefore, I call her Rahab—/_the Harmless Dragon.

18226.text: §¶Now go and write down these words./_Write them in a book./They will stand until the end of time/_as a witness

18227.text: /that these people are stubborn rebels/_who refuse to pay attention to the Lord’s instructions.

18228.text: /They tell the seers,/_“Stop seeing visions!”/They tell the prophets,/_“Don’t tell us what is right./Tell us nice things./_Tell us lies.

18229.text: /Forget all this gloom./_Get off your narrow path./Stop telling us about your/_‘Holy One of Israel.’”

18230.text: ¶This is the reply of the Holy One of Israel:¶▼“Because you despise what I tell you/_and trust instead in oppression and lies,

18231.text: /calamity will come upon you suddenly—/_like a bulging wall that bursts and falls./In an instant it will collapse/_and come crashing down.

18232.text: /You will be smashed like a piece of pottery—/_shattered so completely that/there won’t be a piece big enough/_to carry coals from a fireplace/_or a little water from the well.”

18233.text: ¶This is what the Sovereign Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel, says:/“Only in returning to me/_and resting in me will you be saved./In quietness and confidence is your strength./_But you would have none of it.

18234.text: /You said, ‘No, we will get our help from Egypt./_They will give us swift horses for riding into battle.’/But the only swiftness you are going to see/_is the swiftness of your enemies chasing you!

18235.text: /One of them will chase a thousand of you./_Five of them will make all of you flee./You will be left like a lonely flagpole on a hill/_or a tattered banner on a distant mountaintop.”

18236.text: §¶So the Lord must wait for you to come to him/_so he can show you his love and compassion./For the Lord is a faithful God./_Blessed are those who wait for his help.

18237.text: ¶O people of Zion, who live in Jerusalem,/_you will weep no more./He will be gracious if you ask for help./_He will surely respond to the sound of your cries.

18238.text: /Though the Lord gave you adversity for food/_and suffering for drink,/he will still be with you to teach you./_You will see your teacher with your own eyes.

18239.text: /Your own ears will hear him./_Right behind you a voice will say,/“This is the way you should go,”/_whether to the right or to the left.

18240.text: /Then you will destroy all your silver idols/_and your precious gold images./You will throw them out like filthy rags,/_saying to them, “Good riddance!”

18241.text: ¶Then the Lord will bless you with rain at planting time. There will be wonderful harvests and plenty of pastureland for your livestock.

18242.text: The oxen and donkeys that till the ground will eat good grain, its chaff blown away by the wind.

18243.text: In that day, when your enemies are slaughtered and the towers fall, there will be streams of water flowing down every mountain and hill.

18244.text: The moon will be as bright as the sun, and the sun will be seven times brighter—like the light of seven days in one! So it will be when the Lord begins to heal his people and cure the wounds he gave them.

18245.text: ¶Look! The Lord is coming from far away,/_burning with anger,/_surrounded by thick, rising smoke./His lips are filled with fury;/_his words consume like fire.

18246.text: /His hot breath pours out like a flood/_up to the neck of his enemies./He will sift out the proud nations for destruction./_He will bridle them and lead them away to ruin.

18247.text: ¶But the people of God will sing a song of joy,/_like the songs at the holy festivals./You will be filled with joy,/_as when a flutist leads a group of pilgrims/to Jerusalem, the mountain of the Lord—/_to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: /And the Lord will make his majestic voice heard./_He will display the strength of his mighty arm./It will descend with devouring flames,/_with cloudbursts, thunderstorms, and huge hailstones.

18249.text: /At the Lord’s command, the Assyrians will be shattered./_He will strike them down with his royal scepter.

18250.text: /And as the Lord strikes them with his rod of punishment,/_his people will celebrate with tambourines and harps./_Lifting his mighty arm, he will fight the Assyrians.

18251.text: /Topheth—the place of burning—/_has long been ready for the Assyrian king;/_the pyre is piled high with wood./The breath of the Lord, like fire from a volcano,/_will set it ablaze.

18252.text: §¶What sorrow awaits those who look to Egypt for help,/_trusting their horses, chariots, and charioteers/and depending on the strength of human armies/_instead of looking to the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel.

18253.text: /In his wisdom, the Lord will send great disaster;/_he will not change his mind./He will rise against the wicked/_and against their helpers.

18254.text: /For these Egyptians are mere humans, not God!/_Their horses are puny flesh, not mighty spirits!/When the Lord raises his fist against them,/_those who help will stumble,/and those being helped will fall./_They will all fall down and die together.

18255.text: ¶But this is what the Lord has told me:¶▼“When a strong young lion/_stands growling over a sheep it has killed,/it is not frightened by the shouts and noise/_of a whole crowd of shepherds./In the same way, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_will come down and fight on Mount Zion.

18256.text: /The Lord of Heaven’s Armies will hover over Jerusalem/_and protect it like a bird protecting its nest./He will defend and save the city;/_he will pass over it and rescue it.”

18257.text: ¶Though you are such wicked rebels, my people, come and return to the Lord.

18258.text: I know the glorious day will come when each of you will throw away the gold idols and silver images your sinful hands have made.

18259.text: ¶“The Assyrians will be destroyed,/_but not by the swords of men./The sword of God will strike them,/_and they will panic and flee./The strong young Assyrians/_will be taken away as captives.

18260.text: /Even the strongest will quake with terror,/_and princes will flee when they see your battle flags,”/says the Lord, whose fire burns in Zion,/_whose flame blazes from Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶Look, a righteous king is coming!/_And honest princes will rule under him.

18262.text: /Each one will be like a shelter from the wind/_and a refuge from the storm,/like streams of water in the desert/_and the shadow of a great rock in a parched land.

18263.text: ¶Then everyone who has eyes will be able to see the truth,/_and everyone who has ears will be able to hear it.

18264.text: /Even the hotheads will be full of sense and understanding./_Those who stammer will speak out plainly.

18265.text: /In that day ungodly fools will not be heroes./_Scoundrels will not be respected.

18266.text: /For fools speak foolishness/_and make evil plans./They practice ungodliness/_and spread false teachings about the Lord./They deprive the hungry of food/_and give no water to the thirsty.

18267.text: /The smooth tricks of scoundrels are evil./_They plot crooked schemes./They lie to convict the poor,/_even when the cause of the poor is just.

18268.text: /But generous people plan to do what is generous,/_and they stand firm in their generosity.

18269.text: ¶Listen, you women who lie around in ease./_Listen to me, you who are so smug.

18270.text: /In a short time—just a little more than a year—/_you careless ones will suddenly begin to care./For your fruit crops will fail,/_and the harvest will never take place.

18271.text: /Tremble, you women of ease;/_throw off your complacency./Strip off your pretty clothes,/_and put on burlap to show your grief.

18272.text: /Beat your breasts in sorrow for your bountiful farms/_and your fruitful grapevines.

18273.text: /For your land will be overgrown with thorns and briers./_Your joyful homes and happy towns will be gone.

18274.text: /The palace and the city will be deserted,/_and busy towns will be empty./Wild donkeys will frolic and flocks will graze/_in the empty forts and watchtowers

18275.text: /until at last the Spirit is poured out/_on us from heaven./Then the wilderness will become a fertile field,/_and the fertile field will yield bountiful crops.

18276.text: ¶Justice will rule in the wilderness/_and righteousness in the fertile field.

18277.text: /And this righteousness will bring peace./_Yes, it will bring quietness and confidence forever.

18278.text: /My people will live in safety, quietly at home./_They will be at rest.

18279.text: /Even if the forest should be destroyed/_and the city torn down,

18280.text: /the Lord will greatly bless his people./_Wherever they plant seed, bountiful crops will spring up./_Their cattle and donkeys will graze freely.

18281.text: §¶What sorrow awaits you Assyrians, who have destroyed others/_but have never been destroyed yourselves./You betray others,/_but you have never been betrayed./When you are done destroying,/_you will be destroyed./When you are done betraying,/_you will be betrayed.

18282.text: /But Lord, be merciful to us,/_for we have waited for you./Be our strong arm each day/_and our salvation in times of trouble.

18283.text: /The enemy runs at the sound of your voice./_When you stand up, the nations flee!

18284.text: /Just as caterpillars and locusts strip the fields and vines,/_so the fallen army of Assyria will be stripped!

18285.text: ¶Though the Lord is very great and lives in heaven,/_he will make Jerusalem his home of justice and righteousness.

18286.text: /In that day he will be your sure foundation,/_providing a rich store of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge./_The fear of the Lord will be your treasure.

18287.text: ¶But now your brave warriors weep in public./_Your ambassadors of peace cry in bitter disappointment.

18288.text: /Your roads are deserted;/_no one travels them anymore./The Assyrians have broken their peace treaty/_and care nothing for the promises they made before witnesses./_They have no respect for anyone.

18289.text: /The land of Israel wilts in mourning./_Lebanon withers with shame./The plain of Sharon is now a wilderness./_Bashan and Carmel have been plundered.

18290.text: ¶But the Lord says: “Now I will stand up./_Now I will show my power and might.

18291.text: /You Assyrians produce nothing but dry grass and stubble./_Your own breath will turn to fire and consume you.

18292.text: /Your people will be burned up completely,/_like thornbushes cut down and tossed in a fire.

18293.text: /Listen to what I have done, you nations far away!/_And you that are near, acknowledge my might!”

18294.text: ¶The sinners in Jerusalem shake with fear./_Terror seizes the godless./“Who can live with this devouring fire?” they cry./_“Who can survive this all‐consuming fire?”

18295.text: /Those who are honest and fair,/_who refuse to profit by fraud,/_who stay far away from bribes,/who refuse to listen to those who plot murder,/_who shut their eyes to all enticement to do wrong—

18296.text: /these are the ones who will dwell on high./_The rocks of the mountains will be their fortress./Food will be supplied to them,/_and they will have water in abundance.

18297.text: ¶Your eyes will see the king in all his splendor,/_and you will see a land that stretches into the distance.

18298.text: /You will think back to this time of terror, asking,/“Where are the Assyrian officers/_who counted our towers?/Where are the bookkeepers/_who recorded the plunder taken from our fallen city?”

18299.text: /You will no longer see these fierce, violent people/_with their strange, unknown language.

18300.text: ¶Instead, you will see Zion as a place of holy festivals./_You will see Jerusalem, a city quiet and secure./It will be like a tent whose ropes are taut/_and whose stakes are firmly fixed.

18301.text: /The Lord will be our Mighty One./_He will be like a wide river of protection/that no enemy can cross,/_that no enemy ship can sail upon.

18302.text: /For the Lord is our judge,/_our lawgiver, and our king./_He will care for us and save us.

18303.text: /The enemies’ sails hang loose/_on broken masts with useless tackle./Their treasure will be divided by the people of God./_Even the lame will take their share!

18304.text: /The people of Israel will no longer say,/_“We are sick and helpless,”/_for the Lord will forgive their sins.

18305.text: §¶Come here and listen, O nations of the earth./_Let the world and everything in it hear my words.

18306.text: /For the Lord is enraged against the nations./_His fury is against all their armies./He will completely destroy them,/_dooming them to slaughter.

18307.text: /Their dead will be left unburied,/_and the stench of rotting bodies will fill the land./_The mountains will flow with their blood.

18308.text: /The heavens above will melt away/_and disappear like a rolled‐up scroll./The stars will fall from the sky/_like withered leaves from a grapevine,/_or shriveled figs from a fig tree.

18309.text: ¶And when my sword has finished its work in the heavens,/_it will fall upon Edom,/_the nation I have marked for destruction.

18310.text: /The sword of the Lord is drenched with blood/_and covered with fat—/with the blood of lambs and goats,/_with the fat of rams prepared for sacrifice./Yes, the Lord will offer a sacrifice in the city of Bozrah./_He will make a mighty slaughter in Edom.

18311.text: /Even men as strong as wild oxen will die—/_the young men alongside the veterans./The land will be soaked with blood/_and the soil enriched with fat.

18312.text: ¶For it is the day of the Lord’s revenge,/_the year when Edom will be paid back for all it did to Israel.

18313.text: /The streams of Edom will be filled with burning pitch,/_and the ground will be covered with fire.

18314.text: /This judgment on Edom will never end;/_the smoke of its burning will rise forever./The land will lie deserted from generation to generation./_No one will live there anymore.

18315.text: /It will be haunted by the desert owl and the screech owl,/_the great owl and the raven./For God will measure that land carefully;/_he will measure it for chaos and destruction.

18316.text: /It will be called the Land of Nothing,/_and all its nobles will soon be gone.

18317.text: /Thorns will overrun its palaces;/_nettles and thistles will grow in its forts./The ruins will become a haunt for jackals/_and a home for owls.

18318.text: /Desert animals will mingle there with hyenas,/_their howls filling the night./Wild goats will bleat at one another among the ruins,/_and night creatures will come there to rest.

18319.text: /There the owl will make her nest and lay her eggs./_She will hatch her young and cover them with her wings./And the buzzards will come,/_each one with its mate.

18320.text: ¶Search the book of the Lord,/_and see what he will do./Not one of these birds and animals will be missing,/_and none will lack a mate,/for the Lord has promised this./_His Spirit will make it all come true.

18321.text: /He has surveyed and divided the land/_and deeded it over to those creatures./They will possess it forever,/_from generation to generation.

18322.text: §¶Even the wilderness and desert will be glad in those days./_The wasteland will rejoice and blossom with spring crocuses.

18323.text: /Yes, there will be an abundance of flowers/_and singing and joy!/The deserts will become as green as the mountains of Lebanon,/_as lovely as Mount Carmel or the plain of Sharon./There the Lord will display his glory,/_the splendor of our God.

18324.text: /With this news, strengthen those who have tired hands,/_and encourage those who have weak knees.

18325.text: /Say to those with fearful hearts,/_“Be strong, and do not fear,/for your God is coming to destroy your enemies./_He is coming to save you.”

18326.text: ¶And when he comes, he will open the eyes of the blind/_and unplug the ears of the deaf.

18327.text: /The lame will leap like a deer,/_and those who cannot speak will sing for joy!/Springs will gush forth in the wilderness,/_and streams will water the wasteland.

18328.text: /The parched ground will become a pool,/_and springs of water will satisfy the thirsty land./Marsh grass and reeds and rushes will flourish/_where desert jackals once lived.

18329.text: ¶And a great road will go through that once deserted land./_It will be named the Highway of Holiness./Evil‐minded people will never travel on it./_It will be only for those who walk in God’s ways;/_fools will never walk there.

18330.text: /Lions will not lurk along its course,/_nor any other ferocious beasts./There will be no other dangers./_Only the redeemed will walk on it.

18331.text: /Those who have been ransomed by the Lord will return./_They will enter Jerusalem singing,/_crowned with everlasting joy./Sorrow and mourning will disappear,/_and they will be filled with joy and gladness.

18332.text: §¶In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah’s reign, King Sennacherib of Assyria came to attack the fortified towns of Judah and conquered them.

18333.text: Then the king of Assyria sent his chief of staff from Lachish with a huge army to confront King Hezekiah in Jerusalem. The Assyrians took up a position beside the aqueduct that feeds water into the upper pool, near the road leading to the field where cloth is washed.

18334.text: ¶These are the officials who went out to meet with them: Eliakim son of Hilkiah, the palace administrator; Shebna the court secretary; and Joah son of Asaph, the royal historian.

18335.text: §¶Then the Assyrian king’s chief of staff told them to give this message to Hezekiah:¶“This is what the great king of Assyria says: What are you trusting in that makes you so confident?

18336.text: Do you think that mere words can substitute for military skill and strength? Who are you counting on, that you have rebelled against me?

18337.text: On Egypt? If you lean on Egypt, it will be like a reed that splinters beneath your weight and pierces your hand. Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, is completely unreliable!

18338.text: ¶“But perhaps you will say to me, ‘We are trusting in the Lord our God!’ But isn’t he the one who was insulted by Hezekiah? Didn’t Hezekiah tear down his shrines and altars and make everyone in Judah and Jerusalem worship only at the altar here in Jerusalem?

18339.text: ¶“I’ll tell you what! Strike a bargain with my master, the king of Assyria. I will give you 2,000 horses if you can find that many men to ride on them!

18340.text: With your tiny army, how can you think of challenging even the weakest contingent of my master’s troops, even with the help of Egypt’s chariots and charioteers?

18341.text: What’s more, do you think we have invaded your land without the Lord’s direction? The Lord himself told us, ‘Attack this land and destroy it!’”

18342.text: ¶Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Assyrian chief of staff, “Please speak to us in Aramaic, for we understand it well. Don’t speak in Hebrew, for the people on the wall will hear.”

18343.text: ¶But Sennacherib’s chief of staff replied, “Do you think my master sent this message only to you and your master? He wants all the people to hear it, for when we put this city under siege, they will suffer along with you. They will be so hungry and thirsty that they will eat their own dung and drink their own urine.”

18344.text: ¶Then the chief of staff stood and shouted in Hebrew to the people on the wall, “Listen to this message from the great king of Assyria!

18345.text: This is what the king says: Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you. He will never be able to rescue you.

18346.text: Don’t let him fool you into trusting in the Lord by saying, ‘The Lord will surely rescue us. This city will never fall into the hands of the Assyrian king!’

18347.text: ¶“Don’t listen to Hezekiah! These are the terms the king of Assyria is offering: Make peace with me—open the gates and come out. Then each of you can continue eating from your own grapevine and fig tree and drinking from your own well.

18348.text: Then I will arrange to take you to another land like this one—a land of grain and new wine, bread and vineyards.

18349.text: ¶“Don’t let Hezekiah mislead you by saying, ‘The Lord will rescue us!’ Have the gods of any other nations ever saved their people from the king of Assyria?

18350.text: What happened to the gods of Hamath and Arpad? And what about the gods of Sepharvaim? Did any god rescue Samaria from my power?

18351.text: What god of any nation has ever been able to save its people from my power? So what makes you think that the Lord can rescue Jerusalem from me?”

18352.text: ¶But the people were silent and did not utter a word because Hezekiah had commanded them, “Do not answer him.”

18353.text: ¶Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, the palace administrator; Shebna the court secretary; and Joah son of Asaph, the royal historian, went back to Hezekiah. They tore their clothes in despair, and they went in to see the king and told him what the Assyrian chief of staff had said.

18354.text: §¶When King Hezekiah heard their report, he tore his clothes and put on burlap and went into the Temple of the Lord.

18355.text: And he sent Eliakim the palace administrator, Shebna the court secretary, and the leading priests, all dressed in burlap, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.

18356.text: They told him, “This is what King Hezekiah says: Today is a day of trouble, insults, and disgrace. It is like when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to deliver the baby.

18357.text: But perhaps the Lord your God has heard the Assyrian chief of staff, sent by the king to defy the living God, and will punish him for his words. Oh, pray for those of us who are left!”

18358.text: ¶After King Hezekiah’s officials delivered the king’s message to Isaiah,

18359.text: the prophet replied, “Say to your master, ‘This is what the Lord says: Do not be disturbed by this blasphemous speech against me from the Assyrian king’s messengers.

18360.text: Listen! I myself will move against him, and the king will receive a message that he is needed at home. So he will return to his land, where I will have him killed with a sword.’”

18361.text: ¶Meanwhile, the Assyrian chief of staff left Jerusalem and went to consult the king of Assyria, who had left Lachish and was attacking Libnah.

18362.text: ¶Soon afterward King Sennacherib received word that King Tirhakah of Ethiopia was leading an army to fight against him. Before leaving to meet the attack, he sent messengers back to Hezekiah in Jerusalem with this message:

18363.text: ¶“This message is for King Hezekiah of Judah. Don’t let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you with promises that Jerusalem will not be captured by the king of Assyria.

18364.text: You know perfectly well what the kings of Assyria have done wherever they have gone. They have completely destroyed everyone who stood in their way! Why should you be any different?

18365.text: Have the gods of other nations rescued them—such nations as Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Tel‐assar? My predecessors destroyed them all!

18366.text: What happened to the king of Hamath and the king of Arpad? What happened to the kings of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?”

18367.text: ¶After Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers and read it, he went up to the Lord’s Temple and spread it out before the Lord.

18368.text: And Hezekiah prayed this prayer before the Lord:

18369.text: “O Lord of Heaven’s Armies, God of Israel, you are enthroned between the mighty cherubim! You alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You alone created the heavens and the earth.

18370.text: Bend down, O Lord, and listen! Open your eyes, O Lord, and see! Listen to Sennacherib’s words of defiance against the living God.

18371.text: ¶“It is true, Lord, that the kings of Assyria have destroyed all these nations.

18372.text: And they have thrown the gods of these nations into the fire and burned them. But of course the Assyrians could destroy them! They were not gods at all—only idols of wood and stone shaped by human hands.

18373.text: Now, O Lord our God, rescue us from his power; then all the kingdoms of the earth will know that you alone, O Lord, are God.”

18374.text: §¶Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent this message to Hezekiah: “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Because you prayed about King Sennacherib of Assyria,

18375.text: the Lord has spoken this word against him:¶▼“The virgin daughter of Zion/_despises you and laughs at you./The daughter of Jerusalem/_shakes her head in derision as you flee.

18376.text: ¶“Whom have you been defying and ridiculing?/_Against whom did you raise your voice?/At whom did you look with such haughty eyes?/_It was the Holy One of Israel!

18377.text: /By your messengers you have defied the Lord./_You have said, ‘With my many chariots/I have conquered the highest mountains—/_yes, the remotest peaks of Lebanon./I have cut down its tallest cedars/_and its finest cypress trees./I have reached its farthest heights/_and explored its deepest forests.

18378.text: /I have dug wells in many foreign lands/_and refreshed myself with their water./With the sole of my foot,/_I stopped up all the rivers of Egypt!’

18379.text: ¶“But have you not heard?/_I decided this long ago./Long ago I planned it,/_and now I am making it happen./I planned for you to crush fortified cities/_into heaps of rubble.

18380.text: /That is why their people have so little power/_and are so frightened and confused./They are as weak as grass,/_as easily trampled as tender green shoots./They are like grass sprouting on a housetop,/_scorched before it can grow lush and tall.

18381.text: ¶“But I know you well—/_where you stay/and when you come and go./_I know the way you have raged against me.

18382.text: /And because of your raging against me/_and your arrogance, which I have heard for myself,/I will put my hook in your nose/_and my bit in your mouth./I will make you return/_by the same road on which you came.”

18383.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Here is the proof that what I say is true:¶▼“This year you will eat only what grows up by itself,/_and next year you will eat what springs up from that./But in the third year you will plant crops and harvest them;/_you will tend vineyards and eat their fruit.

18384.text: /And you who are left in Judah,/_who have escaped the ravages of the siege,/will put roots down in your own soil/_and grow up and flourish.

18385.text: /For a remnant of my people will spread out from Jerusalem,/_a group of survivors from Mount Zion./The passionate commitment of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies/_will make this happen!

18386.text: ¶“And this is what the Lord says about the king of Assyria:¶▼“‘His armies will not enter Jerusalem./_They will not even shoot an arrow at it./They will not march outside its gates with their shields/_nor build banks of earth against its walls.

18387.text: /The king will return to his own country/_by the same road on which he came./He will not enter this city,’/_says the Lord.

18388.text: /‘For my own honor and for the sake of my servant David,/_I will defend this city and protect it.’”

18389.text: ¶That night the angel of the Lord went out to the Assyrian camp and killed 185,000 Assyrian soldiers. When the surviving Assyrians woke up the next morning, they found corpses everywhere.

18390.text: Then King Sennacherib of Assyria broke camp and returned to his own land. He went home to his capital of Nineveh and stayed there.

18391.text: ¶One day while he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with their swords. They then escaped to the land of Ararat, and another son, Esarhaddon, became the next king of Assyria.

18392.text: §¶About that time Hezekiah became deathly ill, and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz went to visit him. He gave the king this message: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Set your affairs in order, for you are going to die. You will not recover from this illness.’”

18393.text: ¶When Hezekiah heard this, he turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord,

18394.text: “Remember, O Lord, how I have always been faithful to you and have served you single‐mindedly, always doing what pleases you.” Then he broke down and wept bitterly.

18395.text: ¶Then this message came to Isaiah from the Lord:

18396.text: “Go back to Hezekiah and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of your ancestor David, says: I have heard your prayer and seen your tears. I will add fifteen years to your life,

18397.text: and I will rescue you and this city from the king of Assyria. Yes, I will defend this city.

18398.text: ¶“‘And this is the sign from the Lord to prove that he will do as he promised:

18399.text: I will cause the sun’s shadow to move ten steps backward on the sundial of Ahaz!’” So the shadow on the sundial moved backward ten steps.

18400.text: §¶When King Hezekiah was well again, he wrote this poem:

18401.text: ¶I said, “In the prime of my life,/_must I now enter the place of the dead?/_Am I to be robbed of the rest of my years?”

18402.text: /I said, “Never again will I see the Lord God/_while still in the land of the living./Never again will I see my friends/_or be with those who live in this world.

18403.text: /My life has been blown away/_like a shepherd’s tent in a storm./It has been cut short,/_as when a weaver cuts cloth from a loom./_Suddenly, my life was over.

18404.text: /I waited patiently all night,/_but I was torn apart as though by lions./_Suddenly, my life was over.

18405.text: /Delirious, I chattered like a swallow or a crane,/_and then I moaned like a mourning dove./My eyes grew tired of looking to heaven for help./_I am in trouble, Lord. Help me!”

18406.text: ¶But what could I say?/_For he himself sent this sickness./Now I will walk humbly throughout my years/_because of this anguish I have felt.

18407.text: /Lord, your discipline is good,/_for it leads to life and health./You restore my health/_and allow me to live!

18408.text: /Yes, this anguish was good for me,/_for you have rescued me from death/_and forgiven all my sins.

18409.text: /For the dead cannot praise you;/_they cannot raise their voices in praise./Those who go down to the grave/_can no longer hope in your faithfulness.

18410.text: /Only the living can praise you as I do today./_Each generation tells of your faithfulness to the next.

18411.text: /Think of it—the Lord is ready to heal me!/_I will sing his praises with instruments/every day of my life/_in the Temple of the Lord.

18412.text: ¶Isaiah had said to Hezekiah’s servants, “Make an ointment from figs and spread it over the boil, and Hezekiah will recover.”

18413.text: ¶And Hezekiah had asked, “What sign will prove that I will go to the Temple of the Lord?”

18414.text: §¶Soon after this, Merodach‐baladan son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent Hezekiah his best wishes and a gift. He had heard that Hezekiah had been very sick and that he had recovered.

18415.text: Hezekiah was delighted with the Babylonian envoys and showed them everything in his treasure‐houses—the silver, the gold, the spices, and the aromatic oils. He also took them to see his armory and showed them everything in his royal treasuries! There was nothing in his palace or kingdom that Hezekiah did not show them.

18416.text: ¶Then Isaiah the prophet went to King Hezekiah and asked him, “What did those men want? Where were they from?”¶Hezekiah replied, “They came from the distant land of Babylon.”

18417.text: ¶“What did they see in your palace?” asked Isaiah.¶“They saw everything,” Hezekiah replied. “I showed them everything I own—all my royal treasuries.”

18418.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Listen to this message from the Lord of Heaven’s Armies:

18419.text: ‘The time is coming when everything in your palace—all the treasures stored up by your ancestors until now—will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left,’ says the Lord.

18420.text: ‘Some of your very own sons will be taken away into exile. They will become eunuchs who will serve in the palace of Babylon’s king.’”

18421.text: ¶Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “This message you have given me from the Lord is good.” For the king was thinking, “At least there will be peace and security during my lifetime.”

18423.text: /“Speak tenderly to Jerusalem./Tell her that her sad days are gone/_and her sins are pardoned./Yes, the Lord has punished her twice over/_for all her sins.”

18424.text: ¶Listen! It’s the voice of someone shouting,/“Clear the way through the wilderness/_for the Lord!/Make a straight highway through the wasteland/_for our God!

18425.text: /Fill in the valleys,/_and level the mountains and hills./Straighten the curves,/_and smooth out the rough places.

18426.text: /Then the glory of the Lord will be revealed,/_and all people will see it together./_The Lord has spoken!”

18427.text: ¶A voice said, “Shout!”/_I asked, “What should I shout?”¶“Shout that people are like the grass./_Their beauty fades as quickly/_as the flowers in a field.

18428.text: /The grass withers and the flowers fade/_beneath the breath of the Lord./_And so it is with people.

18429.text: /The grass withers and the flowers fade,/_but the word of our God stands forever.”

18430.text: ¶O Zion, messenger of good news,/_shout from the mountaintops!/Shout it louder, O Jerusalem./_Shout, and do not be afraid./Tell the towns of Judah,/_“Your God is coming!”

18431.text: /Yes, the Sovereign Lord is coming in power./_He will rule with a powerful arm./_See, he brings his reward with him as he comes.

18432.text: /He will feed his flock like a shepherd./_He will carry the lambs in his arms,/holding them close to his heart./_He will gently lead the mother sheep with their young.

18433.text: §¶Who else has held the oceans in his hand?/_Who has measured off the heavens with his fingers?/Who else knows the weight of the earth/_or has weighed the mountains and hills on a scale?

18434.text: /Who is able to advise the Spirit of the Lord?/_Who knows enough to give him advice or teach him?

18435.text: /Has the Lord ever needed anyone’s advice?/_Does he need instruction about what is good?/Did someone teach him what is right/_or show him the path of justice?

18436.text: ¶No, for all the nations of the world/_are but a drop in the bucket./They are nothing more/_than dust on the scales./He picks up the whole earth/_as though it were a grain of sand.

18437.text: /All the wood in Lebanon’s forests/_and all Lebanon’s animals would not be enough/_to make a burnt offering worthy of our God.

18438.text: /The nations of the world are worth nothing to him./_In his eyes they count for less than nothing—/_mere emptiness and froth.

18439.text: ¶To whom can you compare God?/_What image can you find to resemble him?

18440.text: /Can he be compared to an idol formed in a mold,/_overlaid with gold, and decorated with silver chains?

18441.text: /Or if people are too poor for that,/_they might at least choose wood that won’t decay/and a skilled craftsman/_to carve an image that won’t fall down!

18442.text: ¶Haven’t you heard? Don’t you understand?/_Are you deaf to the words of God—/the words he gave before the world began?/_Are you so ignorant?

18443.text: /God sits above the circle of the earth./_The people below seem like grasshoppers to him!/He spreads out the heavens like a curtain/_and makes his tent from them.

18444.text: /He judges the great people of the world/_and brings them all to nothing.

18445.text: /They hardly get started, barely taking root,/_when he blows on them and they wither./_The wind carries them off like chaff.

18446.text: ¶“To whom will you compare me?/_Who is my equal?” asks the Holy One.

18447.text: ¶Look up into the heavens./_Who created all the stars?/He brings them out like an army, one after another,/_calling each by its name./Because of his great power and incomparable strength,/_not a single one is missing.

18448.text: /O Jacob, how can you say the Lord does not see your troubles?/_O Israel, how can you say God ignores your rights?

18449.text: /Have you never heard?/_Have you never understood?/The Lord is the everlasting God,/_the Creator of all the earth./He never grows weak or weary./_No one can measure the depths of his understanding.

18450.text: /He gives power to the weak/_and strength to the powerless.

18451.text: /Even youths will become weak and tired,/_and young men will fall in exhaustion.

18452.text: /But those who trust in the Lord will find new strength./_They will soar high on wings like eagles./They will run and not grow weary./_They will walk and not faint.

18453.text: §¶“Listen in silence before me, you lands beyond the sea./_Bring your strongest arguments./Come now and speak./_The court is ready for your case.

18454.text: ¶“Who has stirred up this king from the east,/_rightly calling him to God’s service?/Who gives this man victory over many nations/_and permits him to trample their kings underfoot?/With his sword, he reduces armies to dust./_With his bow, he scatters them like chaff before the wind.

18455.text: /He chases them away and goes on safely,/_though he is walking over unfamiliar ground.

18456.text: /Who has done such mighty deeds,/_summoning each new generation from the beginning of time?/It is I, the Lord, the First and the Last./_I alone am he.”

18457.text: ¶The lands beyond the sea watch in fear./_Remote lands tremble and mobilize for war.

18458.text: /The idol makers encourage one another,/_saying to each other, “Be strong!”

18459.text: /The carver encourages the goldsmith,/_and the molder helps at the anvil./_“Good,” they say. “It’s coming along fine.”/Carefully they join the parts together,/_then fasten the thing in place so it won’t fall over.

18460.text: ¶“But as for you, Israel my servant,/_Jacob my chosen one,/_descended from Abraham my friend,

18461.text: /I have called you back from the ends of the earth,/_saying, ‘You are my servant.’/For I have chosen you/_and will not throw you away.

18462.text: /Don’t be afraid, for I am with you./_Don’t be discouraged, for I am your God./I will strengthen you and help you./_I will hold you up with my victorious right hand.

18463.text: ¶“See, all your angry enemies lie there,/_confused and humiliated./Anyone who opposes you will die/_and come to nothing.

18464.text: /You will look in vain/_for those who tried to conquer you./Those who attack you/_will come to nothing.

18465.text: /For I hold you by your right hand—/_I, the Lord your God./And I say to you,/_‘Don’t be afraid. I am here to help you.

18466.text: /Though you are a lowly worm, O Jacob,/_don’t be afraid, people of Israel, for I will help you./I am the Lord, your Redeemer./_I am the Holy One of Israel.’

18467.text: /You will be a new threshing instrument/_with many sharp teeth./You will tear your enemies apart,/_making chaff of mountains.

18468.text: /You will toss them into the air,/_and the wind will blow them all away;/_a whirlwind will scatter them./Then you will rejoice in the Lord./_You will glory in the Holy One of Israel.

18469.text: ¶“When the poor and needy search for water and there is none,/_and their tongues are parched from thirst,/then I, the Lord, will answer them./_I, the God of Israel, will never abandon them.

18470.text: /I will open up rivers for them on the high plateaus./_I will give them fountains of water in the valleys./I will fill the desert with pools of water./_Rivers fed by springs will flow across the parched ground.

18471.text: /I will plant trees in the barren desert—/_cedar, acacia, myrtle, olive, cypress, fir, and pine.

18472.text: /I am doing this so all who see this miracle/_will understand what it means—/that it is the Lord who has done this,/_the Holy One of Israel who created it.

18473.text: ¶“Present the case for your idols,”/_says the Lord./“Let them show what they can do,”/_says the King of Israel.

18474.text: /“Let them try to tell us what happened long ago/_so that we may consider the evidence./Or let them tell us what the future holds,/_so we can know what’s going to happen.

18475.text: /Yes, tell us what will occur in the days ahead./_Then we will know you are gods./In fact, do anything—good or bad!/_Do something that will amaze and frighten us.

18476.text: /But no! You are less than nothing and can do nothing at all./_Those who choose you pollute themselves.

18477.text: ¶“But I have stirred up a leader who will approach from the north./_From the east he will call on my name./I will give him victory over kings and princes./_He will trample them as a potter treads on clay.

18478.text: ¶“Who told you from the beginning/_that this would happen?/Who predicted this,/_making you admit that he was right?/_No one said a word!

18479.text: /I was the first to tell Zion,/_‘Look! Help is on the way!’/_I will send Jerusalem a messenger with good news.

18480.text: /Not one of your idols told you this./_Not one gave any answer when I asked.

18481.text: /See, they are all foolish, worthless things./_All your idols are as empty as the wind.

18482.text: §¶“Look at my servant, whom I strengthen./_He is my chosen one, who pleases me./I have put my Spirit upon him./_He will bring justice to the nations.

18483.text: /He will not shout/_or raise his voice in public.

18484.text: /He will not crush the weakest reed/_or put out a flickering candle./_He will bring justice to all who have been wronged.

18485.text: /He will not falter or lose heart/_until justice prevails throughout the earth./_Even distant lands beyond the sea will wait for his instruction.”

18486.text: ¶God, the Lord, created the heavens and stretched them out./_He created the earth and everything in it./He gives breath to everyone,/_life to everyone who walks the earth./And it is he who says,

18487.text: /“I, the Lord, have called you to demonstrate my righteousness./_I will take you by the hand and guard you,/and I will give you to my people, Israel,/_as a symbol of my covenant with them./And you will be a light to guide the nations.

18488.text: /_You will open the eyes of the blind./You will free the captives from prison,/_releasing those who sit in dark dungeons.

18489.text: ¶“I am the Lord; that is my name!/_I will not give my glory to anyone else,/_nor share my praise with carved idols.

18490.text: /Everything I prophesied has come true,/_and now I will prophesy again./I will tell you the future before it happens.”

18491.text: §¶Sing a new song to the Lord!/_Sing his praises from the ends of the earth!/Sing, all you who sail the seas,/_all you who live in distant coastlands.

18492.text: /Join in the chorus, you desert towns;/_let the villages of Kedar rejoice!/Let the people of Sela sing for joy;/_shout praises from the mountaintops!

18493.text: /Let the whole world glorify the Lord;/_let it sing his praise.

18494.text: /The Lord will march forth like a mighty hero;/_he will come out like a warrior, full of fury./He will shout his battle cry/_and crush all his enemies.

18495.text: ¶He will say, “I have long been silent;/_yes, I have restrained myself./But now, like a woman in labor,/_I will cry and groan and pant.

18496.text: /I will level the mountains and hills/_and blight all their greenery./I will turn the rivers into dry land/_and will dry up all the pools.

18497.text: /I will lead blind Israel down a new path,/_guiding them along an unfamiliar way./I will brighten the darkness before them/_and smooth out the road ahead of them./Yes, I will indeed do these things;/_I will not forsake them.

18498.text: /But those who trust in idols,/_who say, ‘You are our gods,’/_will be turned away in shame.

18499.text: §¶“Listen, you who are deaf!/_Look and see, you blind!

18500.text: /Who is as blind as my own people, my servant?/_Who is as deaf as my messenger?/Who is as blind as my chosen people,/_the servant of the Lord?

18501.text: /You see and recognize what is right/_but refuse to act on it./You hear with your ears,/_but you don’t really listen.”

18502.text: ¶Because he is righteous,/_the Lord has exalted his glorious law.

18503.text: /But his own people have been robbed and plundered,/_enslaved, imprisoned, and trapped./They are fair game for anyone/_and have no one to protect them,/_no one to take them back home.

18504.text: ¶Who will hear these lessons from the past/_and see the ruin that awaits you in the future?

18505.text: /Who allowed Israel to be robbed and hurt?/_It was the Lord, against whom we sinned,/for the people would not walk in his path,/_nor would they obey his law.

18506.text: /Therefore, he poured out his fury on them/_and destroyed them in battle./They were enveloped in flames,/_but they still refused to understand./They were consumed by fire,/_but they did not learn their lesson.

18507.text: §¶But now, O Jacob, listen to the Lord who created you./_O Israel, the one who formed you says,/“Do not be afraid, for I have ransomed you./_I have called you by name; you are mine.

18508.text: /When you go through deep waters,/_I will be with you./When you go through rivers of difficulty,/_you will not drown./When you walk through the fire of oppression,/_you will not be burned up;/_the flames will not consume you.

18509.text: /For I am the Lord, your God,/_the Holy One of Israel, your Savior./I gave Egypt as a ransom for your freedom;/_I gave Ethiopia and Seba in your place.

18510.text: /Others were given in exchange for you./_I traded their lives for yours/because you are precious to me./_You are honored, and I love you.

18511.text: ¶“Do not be afraid, for I am with you./_I will gather you and your children from east and west.

18512.text: /I will say to the north and south,/_‘Bring my sons and daughters back to Israel/_from the distant corners of the earth.

18513.text: /Bring all who claim me as their God,/_for I have made them for my glory./_It was I who created them.’”

18514.text: ¶Bring out the people who have eyes but are blind,/_who have ears but are deaf.

18515.text: /Gather the nations together!/_Assemble the peoples of the world!/Which of their idols has ever foretold such things?/_Which can predict what will happen tomorrow?/Where are the witnesses of such predictions?/_Who can verify that they spoke the truth?

18516.text: ¶“But you are my witnesses, O Israel!” says the Lord./_“You are my servant./You have been chosen to know me, believe in me,/_and understand that I alone am God./There is no other God—/_there never has been, and there never will be.

18517.text: /I, yes I, am the Lord,/_and there is no other Savior.

18518.text: /First I predicted your rescue,/_then I saved you and proclaimed it to the world./No foreign god has ever done this./_You are witnesses that I am the only God,”/_says the Lord.

18519.text: /“From eternity to eternity I am God./_No one can snatch anyone out of my hand./_No one can undo what I have done.”

18520.text: §¶This is what the Lord says—your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:¶▼“For your sakes I will send an army against Babylon,/_forcing the Babylonians to flee in those ships they are so proud of.

18521.text: /I am the Lord, your Holy One,/_Israel’s Creator and King.

18522.text: /I am the Lord, who opened a way through the waters,/_making a dry path through the sea.

18523.text: /I called forth the mighty army of Egypt/_with all its chariots and horses./I drew them beneath the waves, and they drowned,/_their lives snuffed out like a smoldering candlewick.

18524.text: ¶“But forget all that—/_it is nothing compared to what I am going to do.

18525.text: /For I am about to do something new./_See, I have already begun! Do you not see it?/I will make a pathway through the wilderness./_I will create rivers in the dry wasteland.

18526.text: /The wild animals in the fields will thank me,/_the jackals and owls, too,/_for giving them water in the desert./Yes, I will make rivers in the dry wasteland/_so my chosen people can be refreshed.

18527.text: /I have made Israel for myself,/_and they will someday honor me before the whole world.

18528.text: ¶“But, dear family of Jacob, you refuse to ask for my help./_You have grown tired of me, O Israel!

18529.text: /You have not brought me sheep or goats for burnt offerings./_You have not honored me with sacrifices,/though I have not burdened and wearied you/_with requests for grain offerings and frankincense.

18530.text: /You have not brought me fragrant calamus/_or pleased me with the fat from sacrifices./Instead, you have burdened me with your sins/_and wearied me with your faults.

18531.text: ¶“I—yes, I alone—will blot out your sins for my own sake/_and will never think of them again.

18532.text: /Let us review the situation together,/_and you can present your case to prove your innocence.

18533.text: /From the very beginning, your first ancestor sinned against me;/_all your leaders broke my laws.

18534.text: /That is why I have disgraced your priests;/_I have decreed complete destruction for Jacob/_and shame for Israel.

18535.text: ¶“But now, listen to me, Jacob my servant,/_Israel my chosen one.

18536.text: /The Lord who made you and helps you says:/Do not be afraid, O Jacob, my servant,/_O dear Israel, my chosen one.

18537.text: /For I will pour out water to quench your thirst/_and to irrigate your parched fields./And I will pour out my Spirit on your descendants,/_and my blessing on your children.

18538.text: /They will thrive like watered grass,/_like willows on a riverbank.

18539.text: /Some will proudly claim, ‘I belong to the Lord.’/_Others will say, ‘I am a descendant of Jacob.’/Some will write the Lord’s name on their hands/_and will take the name of Israel as their own.”

18540.text: §¶This is what the Lord says—Israel’s King and Redeemer, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies:¶▼“I am the First and the Last;/_there is no other God.

18541.text: /Who is like me?/_Let him step forward and prove to you his power./Let him do as I have done since ancient times/_when I established a people and explained its future.

18542.text: /Do not tremble; do not be afraid./_Did I not proclaim my purposes for you long ago?/You are my witnesses—is there any other God?/_No! There is no other Rock—not one!”

18543.text: ¶How foolish are those who manufacture idols./_These prized objects are really worthless./The people who worship idols don’t know this,/_so they are all put to shame.

18544.text: /Who but a fool would make his own god—/_an idol that cannot help him one bit?

18545.text: /All who worship idols will be disgraced/_along with all these craftsmen—mere humans—/_who claim they can make a god./They may all stand together,/_but they will stand in terror and shame.

18546.text: ¶The blacksmith stands at his forge to make a sharp tool,/_pounding and shaping it with all his might./His work makes him hungry and weak./_It makes him thirsty and faint.

18547.text: /Then the wood‐carver measures a block of wood/_and draws a pattern on it./He works with chisel and plane/_and carves it into a human figure./He gives it human beauty/_and puts it in a little shrine.

18548.text: /He cuts down cedars;/_he selects the cypress and the oak;/he plants the pine in the forest/_to be nourished by the rain.

18549.text: /Then he uses part of the wood to make a fire./_With it he warms himself and bakes his bread./Then—yes, it’s true—he takes the rest of it/_and makes himself a god to worship!/He makes an idol/_and bows down in front of it!

18550.text: /He burns part of the tree to roast his meat/_and to keep himself warm./_He says, “Ah, that fire feels good.”

18551.text: /Then he takes what’s left/_and makes his god: a carved idol!/He falls down in front of it,/_worshiping and praying to it./“Rescue me!” he says./_“You are my god!”

18552.text: ¶Such stupidity and ignorance!/_Their eyes are closed, and they cannot see./_Their minds are shut, and they cannot think.

18553.text: /The person who made the idol never stops to reflect,/_“Why, it’s just a block of wood!/I burned half of it for heat/_and used it to bake my bread and roast my meat./How can the rest of it be a god?/_Should I bow down to worship a piece of wood?”

18554.text: /The poor, deluded fool feeds on ashes./_He trusts something that can’t help him at all./Yet he cannot bring himself to ask,/_“Is this idol that I’m holding in my hand a lie?”

18555.text: §¶“Pay attention, O Jacob,/_for you are my servant, O Israel./I, the Lord, made you,/_and I will not forget you.

18556.text: /I have swept away your sins like a cloud./_I have scattered your offenses like the morning mist./Oh, return to me,/_for I have paid the price to set you free.”

18557.text: ¶Sing, O heavens, for the Lord has done this wondrous thing./_Shout for joy, O depths of the earth!/Break into song,/_O mountains and forests and every tree!/For the Lord has redeemed Jacob/_and is glorified in Israel.

18558.text: ¶This is what the Lord says—/_your Redeemer and Creator:/“I am the Lord, who made all things./_I alone stretched out the heavens./Who was with me/_when I made the earth?

18559.text: /I expose the false prophets as liars/_and make fools of fortune‐tellers./I cause the wise to give bad advice,/_thus proving them to be fools.

18560.text: /But I carry out the predictions of my prophets!/_By them I say to Jerusalem, ‘People will live here again,’/and to the towns of Judah, ‘You will be rebuilt;/_I will restore all your ruins!’

18561.text: /When I speak to the rivers and say, ‘Dry up!’/_they will be dry.

18562.text: /When I say of Cyrus, ‘He is my shepherd,’/_he will certainly do as I say./He will command, ‘Rebuild Jerusalem’;/_he will say, ‘Restore the Temple.’”

18563.text: §¶This is what the Lord says to Cyrus, his anointed one,/_whose right hand he will empower./Before him, mighty kings will be paralyzed with fear./_Their fortress gates will be opened,/_never to shut again.

18564.text: /This is what the Lord says:¶“I will go before you, Cyrus,/_and level the mountains./I will smash down gates of bronze/_and cut through bars of iron.

18565.text: /And I will give you treasures hidden in the darkness—/_secret riches./I will do this so you may know that I am the Lord,/_the God of Israel, the one who calls you by name.

18566.text: ¶“And why have I called you for this work?/_Why did I call you by name when you did not know me?/It is for the sake of Jacob my servant,/_Israel my chosen one.

18567.text: /I am the Lord;/_there is no other God./I have equipped you for battle,/_though you don’t even know me,

18568.text: /so all the world from east to west/_will know there is no other God./I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18569.text: /_I create the light and make the darkness./I send good times and bad times./_I, the Lord, am the one who does these things.

18570.text: ¶“Open up, O heavens,/_and pour out your righteousness./Let the earth open wide/_so salvation and righteousness can sprout up together./_I, the Lord, created them.

18571.text: ¶“What sorrow awaits those who argue with their Creator./_Does a clay pot argue with its maker?/Does the clay dispute with the one who shapes it, saying,/_‘Stop, you’re doing it wrong!’/Does the pot exclaim,/_‘How clumsy can you be?’

18572.text: /How terrible it would be if a newborn baby said to its father,/_‘Why was I born?’/or if it said to its mother,/_‘Why did you make me this way?’”

18573.text: ¶This is what the Lord says—/_the Holy One of Israel and your Creator:/“Do you question what I do for my children?/_Do you give me orders about the work of my hands?

18574.text: /I am the one who made the earth/_and created people to live on it./With my hands I stretched out the heavens./_All the stars are at my command.

18575.text: /I will raise up Cyrus to fulfill my righteous purpose,/_and I will guide his actions./He will restore my city and free my captive people—/_without seeking a reward!/_I, the Lord of Heaven’s Armies, have spoken!”

18576.text: §¶This is what the Lord says:¶▼“You will rule the Egyptians,/_the Ethiopians, and the Sabeans./They will come to you with all their merchandise,/_and it will all be yours./They will follow you as prisoners in chains./_They will fall to their knees in front of you and say,/‘God is with you, and he is the only God./_There is no other.’”

18577.text: ¶Truly, O God of Israel, our Savior,/_you work in mysterious ways.

18578.text: /All craftsmen who make idols will be humiliated./_They will all be disgraced together.

18579.text: /But the Lord will save the people of Israel/_with eternal salvation./Throughout everlasting ages,/_they will never again be humiliated and disgraced.

18580.text: ¶For the Lord is God,/_and he created the heavens and earth/_and put everything in place./He made the world to be lived in,/_not to be a place of empty chaos./“I am the Lord,” he says,/_“and there is no other.

18581.text: /I publicly proclaim bold promises./_I do not whisper obscurities in some dark corner./I would not have told the people of Israel to seek me/_if I could not be found./I, the Lord, speak only what is true/_and declare only what is right.

18582.text: ¶“Gather together and come,/_you fugitives from surrounding nations./What fools they are who carry around their wooden idols/_and pray to gods that cannot save!

18583.text: /Consult together, argue your case./_Get together and decide what to say./Who made these things known so long ago?/_What idol ever told you they would happen?/Was it not I, the Lord?/_For there is no other God but me,/a righteous God and Savior./_There is none but me.

18584.text: /Let all the world look to me for salvation!/_For I am God; there is no other.

18585.text: /I have sworn by my own name;/_I have spoken the truth,/_and I will never go back on my word:/Every knee will bend to me,/_and every tongue will declare allegiance to me.”

18586.text: /The people will declare,/_“The Lord is the source of all my righteousness and strength.”/And all who were angry with him/_will come to him and be ashamed.

18587.text: /In the Lord all the generations of Israel will be justified,/_and in him they will boast.

18588.text: §¶Bel and Nebo, the gods of Babylon,/_bow as they are lowered to the ground./They are being hauled away on ox carts./_The poor beasts stagger under the weight.

18589.text: /Both the idols and their owners are bowed down./_The gods cannot protect the people,/and the people cannot protect the gods./_They go off into captivity together.

18590.text: ¶“Listen to me, descendants of Jacob,/_all you who remain in Israel./I have cared for you since you were born./_Yes, I carried you before you were born.

18591.text: /I will be your God throughout your lifetime—/_until your hair is white with age./I made you, and I will care for you./_I will carry you along and save you.

18592.text: ¶“To whom will you compare me?/_Who is my equal?

18593.text: /Some people pour out their silver and gold/_and hire a craftsman to make a god from it./_Then they bow down and worship it!

18594.text: /They carry it around on their shoulders,/_and when they set it down, it stays there./_It can’t even move!/And when someone prays to it, there is no answer./_It can’t rescue anyone from trouble.

18595.text: ¶“Do not forget this! Keep it in mind!/_Remember this, you guilty ones.

18596.text: /Remember the things I have done in the past./_For I alone am God!/_I am God, and there is none like me.

18597.text: /Only I can tell you the future/_before it even happens./Everything I plan will come to pass,/_for I do whatever I wish.

18598.text: /I will call a swift bird of prey from the east—/_a leader from a distant land to come and do my bidding./I have said what I would do,/_and I will do it.

18599.text: ¶“Listen to me, you stubborn people/_who are so far from doing right.

18600.text: /For I am ready to set things right,/_not in the distant future, but right now!/I am ready to save Jerusalem/_and show my glory to Israel.

18601.text: §¶“Come down, virgin daughter of Babylon, and sit in the dust./_For your days of sitting on a throne have ended./O daughter of Babylonia, never again will you be/_the lovely princess, tender and delicate.

18602.text: /Take heavy millstones and grind flour./_Remove your veil, and strip off your robe./_Expose yourself to public view.

18603.text: /You will be naked and burdened with shame./_I will take vengeance against you without pity.”

18604.text: ¶Our Redeemer, whose name is the Lord of Heaven’s Armies,/_is the Holy One of Israel.

18605.text: ¶“O beautiful Babylon, sit now in darkness and silence./_Never again will you be known as the queen of kingdoms.

18606.text: /For I was angry with my chosen people/_and punished them by letting them fall into your hands./But you, Babylon, showed them no mercy./_You oppressed even the elderly.

18607.text: /You said, ‘I will reign forever as queen of the world!’/_You did not reflect on your actions/_or think about their consequences.

18608.text: ¶“Listen to this, you pleasure‐loving kingdom,/_living at ease and feeling secure./You say, ‘I am the only one, and there is no other./_I will never be a widow or lose my children.’

18609.text: /Well, both these things will come upon you in a moment:/_widowhood and the loss of your children./Yes, these calamities will come upon you,/_despite all your witchcraft and magic.

18610.text: ¶“You felt secure in your wickedness./_‘No one sees me,’ you said./But your ‘wisdom’ and ‘knowledge’ have led you astray,/_and you said, ‘I am the only one, and there is no other.’

18611.text: /So disaster will overtake you,/_and you won’t be able to charm it away./Calamity will fall upon you,/_and you won’t be able to buy your way out./A catastrophe will strike you suddenly,/_one for which you are not prepared.

18612.text: ¶“Now use your magical charms!/_Use the spells you have worked at all these years!/Maybe they will do you some good./_Maybe they can make someone afraid of you.

18613.text: /All the advice you receive has made you tired./_Where are all your astrologers,/those stargazers who make predictions each month?/_Let them stand up and save you from what the future holds.

18614.text: /But they are like straw burning in a fire;/_they cannot save themselves from the flame./You will get no help from them at all;/_their hearth is no place to sit for warmth.

18615.text: /And all your friends,/_those with whom you’ve done business since childhood,/will go their own ways,/_turning a deaf ear to your cries.

18616.text: §¶“Listen to me, O family of Jacob,/_you who are called by the name of Israel/_and born into the family of Judah./Listen, you who take oaths in the name of the Lord/_and call on the God of Israel./You don’t keep your promises,

18617.text: /_even though you call yourself the holy city/and talk about depending on the God of Israel,/_whose name is the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.

18618.text: /Long ago I told you what was going to happen./_Then suddenly I took action,/_and all my predictions came true.

18619.text: /For I know how stubborn and obstinate you are./_Your necks are as unbending as iron./_Your heads are as hard as bronze.

18620.text: /That is why I told you what would happen;/_I told you beforehand what I was going to do./Then you could never say, ‘My idols did it./_My wooden image and metal god commanded it to happen!’

18621.text: /You have heard my predictions and seen them fulfilled,/_but you refuse to admit it./Now I will tell you new things,/_secrets you have not yet heard.

18622.text: /They are brand new, not things from the past./_So you cannot say, ‘We knew that all the time!’

18623.text: ¶“Yes, I will tell you of things that are entirely new,/_things you never heard of before./For I know so well what traitors you are./_You have been rebels from birth.

18624.text: /Yet for my own sake and for the honor of my name,/_I will hold back my anger and not wipe you out.

18625.text: /I have refined you, but not as silver is refined./_Rather, I have refined you in the furnace of suffering.

18626.text: /I will rescue you for my sake—/_yes, for my own sake!/I will not let my reputation be tarnished,/_and I will not share my glory with idols!

18627.text: §¶“Listen to me, O family of Jacob,/_Israel my chosen one!/I alone am God,/_the First and the Last.

18628.text: /It was my hand that laid the foundations of the earth,/_my right hand that spread out the heavens above./When I call out the stars,/_they all appear in order.”

18629.text: ¶Have any of your idols ever told you this?/_Come, all of you, and listen:/The Lord has chosen Cyrus as his ally./_He will use him to put an end to the empire of Babylon/_and to destroy the Babylonian armies.

18630.text: ¶“I have said it: I am calling Cyrus!/_I will send him on this errand and will help him succeed.

18631.text: /Come closer, and listen to this./_From the beginning I have told you plainly what would happen.”¶And now the Sovereign Lord and his Spirit/_have sent me with this message.

18632.text: /This is what the Lord says—/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/“I am the Lord your God,/_who teaches you what is good for you/_and leads you along the paths you should follow.

18633.text: /Oh, that you had listened to my commands!/_Then you would have had peace flowing like a gentle river/_and righteousness rolling over you like waves in the sea.

18634.text: /Your descendants would have been like the sands along the seashore—/_too many to count!/There would have been no need for your destruction,/_or for cutting off your family name.”

18635.text: ¶Yet even now, be free from your captivity!/_Leave Babylon and the Babylonians./Sing out this message!/_Shout it to the ends of the earth!/The Lord has redeemed his servants,/_the people of Israel.

18636.text: /They were not thirsty/_when he led them through the desert./He divided the rock,/_and water gushed out for them to drink.

18637.text: /“But there is no peace for the wicked,”/_says the Lord.

18638.text: §¶Listen to me, all you in distant lands!/_Pay attention, you who are far away!/The Lord called me before my birth;/_from within the womb he called me by name.

18639.text: /He made my words of judgment as sharp as a sword./_He has hidden me in the shadow of his hand./_I am like a sharp arrow in his quiver.

18640.text: ¶He said to me, “You are my servant, Israel,/_and you will bring me glory.”

18641.text: ¶I replied, “But my work seems so useless!/_I have spent my strength for nothing and to no purpose./Yet I leave it all in the Lord’s hand;/_I will trust God for my reward.”

18642.text: ¶And now the Lord speaks—/_the one who formed me in my mother’s womb to be his servant,/_who commissioned me to bring Israel back to him./The Lord has honored me,/_and my God has given me strength.

18643.text: /He says, “You will do more than restore the people of Israel to me./_I will make you a light to the Gentiles,/_and you will bring my salvation to the ends of the earth.”

18644.text: ¶The Lord, the Redeemer/_and Holy One of Israel,/says to the one who is despised and rejected by the nations,/_to the one who is the servant of rulers:/“Kings will stand at attention when you pass by./_Princes will also bow low/because of the Lord, the faithful one,/_the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen you.”

18645.text: §¶This is what the Lord says:¶▼“At just the right time, I will respond to you./_On the day of salvation I will help you./I will protect you and give you to the people/_as my covenant with them./Through you I will reestablish the land of Israel/_and assign it to its own people again.

18646.text: /I will say to the prisoners, ‘Come out in freedom,’/_and to those in darkness, ‘Come into the light.’/They will be my sheep, grazing in green pastures/_and on hills that were previously bare.

18647.text: /They will neither hunger nor thirst./_The searing sun will not reach them anymore./For the Lord in his mercy will lead them;/_he will lead them beside cool waters.

18648.text: /And I will make my mountains into level paths for them./_The highways will be raised above the valleys.

18649.text: /See, my people will return from far away,/_from lands to the north and west,/_and from as far south as Egypt.”

18650.text: ¶Sing for joy, O heavens!/_Rejoice, O earth!/_Burst into song, O mountains!/For the Lord has comforted his people/_and will have compassion on them in their suffering.

18651.text: ¶Yet Jerusalem says, “The Lord has deserted us;/_the Lord has forgotten us.”

18652.text: ¶“Never! Can a mother forget her nursing child?/_Can she feel no love for the child she has borne?/But even if that were possible,/_I would not forget you!

18653.text: /See, I have written your name on the palms of my hands./_Always in my mind is a picture of Jerusalem’s walls in ruins.

18654.text: /Soon your descendants will come back,/_and all who are trying to destroy you will go away.

18655.text: /Look around you and see,/_for all your children will come back to you./As surely as I live,” says the Lord,/_“they will be like jewels or bridal ornaments for you to display.

18656.text: ¶“Even the most desolate parts of your abandoned land/_will soon be crowded with your people./Your enemies who enslaved you/_will be far away.

18657.text: /The generations born in exile will return and say,/_‘We need more room! It’s crowded here!’

18658.text: /Then you will think to yourself,/_‘Who has given me all these descendants?/For most of my children were killed,/_and the rest were carried away into exile./I was left here all alone./_Where did all these people come from?/Who bore these children?/_Who raised them for me?’”

18659.text: ¶This is what the Sovereign Lord says:/_“See, I will give a signal to the godless nations./They will carry your little sons back to you in their arms;/_they will bring your daughters on their shoulders.

18660.text: /Kings and queens will serve you/_and care for all your needs./They will bow to the earth before you/_and lick the dust from your feet./Then you will know that I am the Lord./_Those who trust in me will never be put to shame.”

18661.text: ¶Who can snatch the plunder of war from the hands of a warrior?/_Who can demand that a tyrant let his captives go?

18662.text: /But the Lord says,/“The captives of warriors will be released,/_and the plunder of tyrants will be retrieved./For I will fight those who fight you,/_and I will save your children.

18663.text: /I will feed your enemies with their own flesh./_They will be drunk with rivers of their own blood./All the world will know that I, the Lord,/_am your Savior and your Redeemer,/_the Mighty One of Israel.”

18664.text: ¶This is what the Lord says:¶▼“Was your mother sent away because I divorced her?/_Did I sell you as slaves to my creditors?/No, you were sold because of your sins./_And your mother, too, was taken because of your sins.

18665.text: /Why was no one there when I came?/_Why didn’t anyone answer when I called?/Is it because I have no power to rescue?/_No, that is not the reason!/For I can speak to the sea and make it dry up!/_I can turn rivers into deserts covered with dying fish.

18666.text: /I dress the skies in darkness,/_covering them with clothes of mourning.”

18667.text: §¶The Sovereign Lord has given me his words of wisdom,/_so that I know how to comfort the weary./Morning by morning he wakens me/_and opens my understanding to his will.

18668.text: /The Sovereign Lord has spoken to me,/_and I have listened./_I have not rebelled or turned away.

18669.text: /I offered my back to those who beat me/_and my cheeks to those who pulled out my beard./I did not hide my face/_from mockery and spitting.

18670.text: ¶Because the Sovereign Lord helps me,/_I will not be disgraced./Therefore, I have set my face like a stone,/_determined to do his will./_And I know that I will not be put to shame.

18671.text: /He who gives me justice is near./_Who will dare to bring charges against me now?/Where are my accusers?/_Let them appear!

18672.text: /See, the Sovereign Lord is on my side!/_Who will declare me guilty?/All my enemies will be destroyed/_like old clothes that have been eaten by moths!

18673.text: ¶Who among you fears the Lord/_and obeys his servant?/If you are walking in darkness,/_without a ray of light,/trust in the Lord/_and rely on your God.

18674.text: /But watch out, you who live in your own light/_and warm yourselves by your own fires./This is the reward you will receive from me:/_You will soon fall down in great torment.

18675.text: §¶“Listen to me, all who hope for deliverance—/_all who seek the Lord!/Consider the rock from which you were cut,/_the quarry from which you were mined.
